Paragraph:
This item represents the carrying amount on the entity's balance sheet of its investment in common stock of an equity method investee. This is not an indicator of the fair value of the investment, rather it is the initial cost adjusted for the entity's share of earnings and losses of the investee, adjusted for any distributions (dividends) and other than temporary impairment (OTTI) losses recognized.

Paragraph:

Paragraph:
For receivables acquired in a business combination, excluding certain loans and debt securities acquired in a transfer (as defined), this element represents the best estimate at the acquisition date of the contractual cash flows not expected to be collected, by major class of receivable, such as loans, direct finance leases (as defined), and any other class of receivables.

Paragraph:
Reference 1: http://www.xbrl.org/2003/role/presentationRef

 -SubTopic 20
 -Section 50
 -Paragraph 1
 -Subparagraph (b)(3)
 -URI http://asc.fasb.org/extlink&oid=73530397&loc=d3e4845-128472

Paragraph:
For receivables acquired in a business combination, excluding certain loans and debt securities acquired in a transfer (as defined), this element represents the gross contractual amounts receivable, by major class of receivable, such as loans, direct finance leases (as defined), and any other class of receivables.

Paragraph:
The aggregate expense charged against earnings to allocate the cost of intangible assets (nonphysical assets not used in production) in a systematic and rational manner to the periods expected to benefit from such assets. As a noncash expense, this element is added back to net income when calculating cash provided by or used in operations using the indirect method.

Paragraph:
The aggregate amount assigned to a major class of finite-lived intangible assets acquired either individually or as part of a group of assets (in either an asset acquisition or business combination). A major class is composed of intangible assets that can be grouped together because they are similar, either by their nature or by their use in the operations of a company.

Paragraph:
No definition available.

Paragraph:

Paragraph:
The fair value amount of long-term debt whether such amount is presented as a separate caption or as a parenthetical disclosure. Additionally, this element may be used in connection with the fair value disclosures required in the footnote disclosures to the financial statements. The element may be used in both the balance sheet and disclosure in the same submission.

Paragraph:
Amount of deferred revenue as of balance sheet date. Deferred revenue represents collections of cash or other assets related to a revenue producing activity for which revenue has not yet been recognized. Generally, an entity records deferred revenue when it receives consideration from a customer before achieving certain criteria that must be met for revenue to be recognized in conformity with GAAP.

Paragraph:

Paragraph:
Number of shares that have been repurchased during the period and have not been retired and are not held in treasury. Some state laws may govern the circumstances under which an entity may acquire its own stock and prescribe the accounting treatment therefore. This element is used when state law does not recognize treasury stock.

Paragraph:
Line items represent financial concepts included in a table. These concepts are used to disclose reportable information associated with domain members defined in one or many axes to the table.

Paragraph:
No definition available.

Paragraph:
Accumulated change in equity from transactions and other events and circumstances from non-owner sources, net of tax effect, at period end. Excludes Net Income (Loss), and accumulated changes in equity from transactions resulting from investments by owners and distributions to owners. Includes foreign currency translation items, certain pension adjustments, unrealized gains and losses on certain investments in debt and equity securities, other than temporary impairment (OTTI) losses related to factors other than credit losses on available-for-sale and held-to-maturity debt securities that an entity does not intend to sell and it is not more likely than not that the entity will be required to sell before recovery of the amortized cost basis, as well as changes in the fair value of derivatives related to the effective portion of a designated cash flow hedge.

Paragraph:

Paragraph:
Compensation Related Costs Disclosure [Line Items]

Paragraph:
No definition available.

Paragraph:
Disclosure of the extent of enterprise reliance on its major customers. For example, includes revenues from transactions with a single external customer amounting to 10 percent or more of the entity's revenues, the total amount of revenues from each such customer, and the identity of the segment or segments reporting the revenues. A group of entities that the entity knows to be under common control generally will be considered a single customer for inclusion in this item. The federal government, a state government, a local government (for example, a county or municipality), or a foreign government each will generally be considered as a single customer for inclusion in this item.

Paragraph:
Reference 1: http://www.xbrl.org/2003/role/presentationRef
 -Publisher FASB
 -Name Accounting Standards Codification
 -Topic 280
 -SubTopic 10
 -Section 50
 -Paragraph 42
 -URI http://asc.fasb.org/extlink&oid=68060357&loc=d3e9054-108599

Total revenue from sale of goods and services rendered during the reporting period, in the normal course of business, reduced by sales returns and allowances, and sales discounts.

Reference 1: http://www.xbrl.org/2003/role/presentationRef

 -Section S99

['', '\x95', '', 'A competing vertically-integrated model, in which a single firm controls the software and hardware elements of a product and related services, has succeeded\nwith some consumer products such as personal computers, tablets, phones, gaming consoles, and wearables. Competitors pursuing this model also earn revenue from services integrated with the hardware and software platform. We also offer some\nvertically-integrated hardware and software products and services. To the extent we shift a portion of our business to a vertically integrated model we increase our cost of revenue and reduce our operating margins.']

Table:
['', '\x95', '', 'We derive substantial revenue from licenses of Windows operating systems on personal computers. We face significant competition from competing platforms\ndeveloped for new devices and form factors such as smartphones and tablet computers. These devices compete on multiple bases including price and the perceived utility of the device and its platform. Users are increasingly turning to these devices to\nperform functions that in the past were performed by personal computers. Even if many users view these devices as complementary to a personal computer, the prevalence of these devices may make it more difficult to']

Table:
['', 'attract application developers to our PC operating system platforms. Competing with operating systems licensed at low or no cost may decrease our PC operating system margins. In addition, some of\nour devices compete with products made by our OEM partners, which may affect their commitment to our platform.']

Table:
['', '\x95', '', 'Competing platforms have application marketplaces (sometimes referred to as \x93stores\x94) with scale and significant installed bases. The variety and\nutility of applications available on a platform are important to device purchasing decisions. Users incur costs to move data and buy new applications when switching platforms. To compete, we must successfully\xa0enlist developers to write\napplications for our marketplace and ensure that these applications have high quality, customer appeal, and value. Efforts to compete with competitors\x92 application marketplaces may increase our cost of revenue and lower our operating margins.']

Table:
['', '\x95', '', 'Even as we transition to a mobile-first and cloud-first strategy, the license-based proprietary software model generates most of our software revenue. We bear\nthe costs of converting original ideas into software products through investments in research and development, offsetting these costs with the revenue received from licensing our products. Many of our competitors also develop and sell software to\nbusinesses and consumers under this model.']

Table:
['', '\x95', '', 'Other competitors develop and offer free applications, online services and content, and make money by selling third-party advertising. Advertising revenue\nfunds development of products and services these competitors provide to users at no or little cost, competing directly with our revenue-generating products.']

Table:
['', '\x95', '', 'Some companies compete with us using an open source business model by modifying and then distributing open source software at nominal cost to end-users, and\nearning revenue on advertising or complementary services and products. These firms do not bear the full costs of research and development for the software. Some open source software vendors develop software that mimics the features and functionality\nof our products.']

Table:
['', '\x95', '', 'Continuing to bring to market compelling cloud-based experiences that generate increasing traffic and market share.']

['(a)', 'Reflects the impact of the net revenue deferral from Windows 10 of $6.6 billion, which decreased operating income, net income, and diluted earnings per\nshare (\x93EPS\x94) by $6.6 billion, $4.6 billion, and $0.58, respectively.']

Table:
['(b)', 'Includes $630 million of asset impairment charges related to our phone business, and $480 million of restructuring charges associated with our phone\nbusiness restructuring plans, which together decreased operating income, net income, and diluted EPS by $1.1 billion, $895 million, and $0.11, respectively.']

Table:
['(c)', 'Includes $7.5 billion of goodwill and asset impairment charges related to our phone business, and $2.5 billion of integration and restructuring expenses,\nprimarily associated with our phone business restructuring plans, which together decreased operating income, net income, and diluted EPS by $10.0 billion, $9.5 billion, and $1.15, respectively.']

Table:
['(d)', 'On April\xa025, 2014, we acquired substantially all of NDS. NDS has been included in our consolidated results of operations starting on the acquisition\ndate.']

Table:
['(e)', 'Includes a charge related to a fine imposed by the European Commission in March 2013 which decreased operating income and net income by $733 million\n(\x80561 million) and diluted EPS by $0.09. Also includes a charge for Surface RT inventory adjustments recorded in the fourth quarter of fiscal year 2013, which decreased operating income, net income, and diluted EPS by $900 million, $596\nmillion, and $0.07, respectively.']

Table:
['(f)', 'Includes a goodwill impairment charge related to our previous Online Services Division business segment (related to More Personal Computing under our\ncurrent segment structure) which decreased operating income and net income by $6.2 billion and diluted EPS by $0.73.']

Table:
['(g)', 'Reflects the impact of the adoption of the new accounting standard in fiscal year 2016 related to balance sheet classification of deferred taxes. See Note\n1 \x96 Accounting Policies of the Notes to Financial Statements (Part II, Item\xa08 of this Form 10-K) for further discussion.']

['', '\x95', '', 'Office Commercial revenue increased $135 million or 1%, driven by higher revenue from Office 365 commercial, mainly due to growth in subscribers, offset by\nlower transactional license volume, reflecting a continued shift to Office 365 commercial and a decline in the business PC market. Revenue included an unfavorable foreign currency impact of approximately 6%.']

Table:
['', '\x95', '', 'Office Consumer revenue decreased $69 million or 2%, driven by a decline in the consumer PC market, offset in part by higher revenue from Office 365 consumer,\nmainly due to growth in subscribers. Revenue included an unfavorable foreign currency impact of approximately 4%.']

Table:
['', '\x95', '', 'Dynamics revenue increased 4%, mainly due to higher revenue from Dynamics CRM Online, driven by seat growth. Revenue included an unfavorable foreign currency\nimpact of approximately 6%.']

Table:
['', '\x95', '', 'Server products and cloud services revenue grew $686 million or 4%, driven by revenue growth from Azure of 113%, offset in part by a decline in transactional\nrevenue from our on-premises server products. Revenue included an unfavorable foreign currency impact of approximately 5%.']

Table:
['', '\x95', '', 'Enterprise Services revenue grew $536 million or 11%, mainly due to growth in Premier Support Services. Revenue included an unfavorable foreign currency\nimpact of approximately 5%.']

Table:
['', '\x95', '', 'Devices revenue decreased $3.7 billion or 32%, mainly due to lower revenue from phones, driven by the change in strategy for the phone business, offset in\npart by higher Microsoft Surface (\x93Surface\x94) revenue.']

Table:
['', 'Phone revenue decreased $4.2 billion or 56%, as we sold 13.8\xa0million Microsoft Lumia (\x93Lumia\x94) phones and 75.5\xa0million other phones in fiscal year 2016, compared with\n36.8\xa0million and 126.8\xa0million sold, respectively, in fiscal year 2015. Surface revenue increased $486 million or 13%, primarily driven by the release of Surface Pro 4 and Surface Book in the second quarter of fiscal year 2016, as well as\nthe release of Surface 3 in the fourth quarter of fiscal year 2015, offset in part by a decline in revenue from Surface Pro 3. Devices revenue included an unfavorable foreign currency impact of approximately 3%.']

Table:
['', '\x95', '', 'Windows revenue decreased $871 million or 5%, mainly due to lower revenue from patent licensing, Windows OEM licensing (\x93Windows OEM\x94), and Windows\nPhone licensing. Patent licensing revenue decreased 27%, due to a decline in license revenue per unit and licensed units. Windows OEM revenue decreased 1%. Windows OEM Pro revenue declined 6%, driven by a decline in the business PC market. Windows\nOEM non-Pro revenue increased 7%, outperforming the consumer PC market, driven by a higher mix of premium licenses sold. Windows Phone licensing revenue decreased 64%, driven by the recognition of deferred revenue in fiscal year 2015 from Windows\nPhone 8. Windows revenue included an unfavorable foreign currency impact of approximately 2%.']

Table:
['', '\x95', '', 'Search advertising revenue increased $1.7 billion or 46%. Search advertising revenue, excluding traffic acquisition costs, increased 17%, primarily driven by\ngrowth in Bing, due to higher revenue per search and search volume. Search advertising revenue included an unfavorable foreign currency impact of approximately 2%.']

Table:
['', '\x95', '', 'Gaming revenue increased $132 million or 1%, primarily due to higher revenue from Xbox Live and video games, offset in part by lower Xbox hardware revenue.\nXbox Live revenue increased 17%, driven by higher revenue per transaction and volume of transactions. Video games revenue grew 34%, driven by the launch of Halo 5 and sales of Minecraft. We acquired Mojang AB (\x93Mojang\x94), the Swedish video\ngame developer of the Minecraft gaming franchise, in November 2014. Xbox hardware revenue decreased 16%, mainly due to lower prices of Xbox One consoles sold and a decline in Xbox 360 console volume, offset in part by higher Xbox One console volume.\nGaming revenue included an unfavorable foreign currency impact of approximately 4%.']

Table:
['', '\x95', '', 'Office Consumer revenue decreased $624 million or 17%, driven by declines in the Japan PC market, where Office is predominantly pre-installed on new PCs,\noffset in part by subscriber growth of Office 365 consumer.']

Table:
['', '\x95', '', 'Office Commercial revenue decreased $152 million or 1%, driven by lower transactional license volume, reflecting a decline in the business PC market following\nWindows XP end of support in the prior year, and declines in Japan, offset in part by subscriber growth and higher premium mix of Office 365 commercial.']

Table:
['', '\x95', '', 'Dynamics revenue grew 12%, mainly due to higher revenue from Dynamics CRM Online and Dynamics ERP products. Dynamics users increased, with 30% growth in\nnumber of Dynamics paid seats, and we ended fiscal year 2015 with over eight million paid seats.']

Table:
['', '\x95', '', 'Server products and cloud services revenue grew $1.6 billion or 9%, primarily driven by higher premium mix of Microsoft SQL Server, Windows Server, and System\nCenter, as well as continued revenue growth from Azure.']

Table:
['', '\x95', '', 'Enterprise Services revenue grew $325 million or 7%, mainly due to growth in Premier Support Services.']

Table:
['', '\x95', '', 'Devices revenue increased $7.0 billion or 152%, mainly due to a full year of phone sales and higher Surface revenue. Devices revenue included an unfavorable\nforeign currency impact of approximately 5%. Phones revenue increased $5.5 billion, as we sold 36.8\xa0million Lumia phones and 126.8\xa0million other phones in fiscal year 2015, compared with 5.8\xa0million and 30.3\xa0million sold,\nrespectively, in fiscal year 2014 following the acquisition of Nokia Corporation\x92s (\x93Nokia\x94) Devices and Services business (\x93NDS\x94). We acquired NDS in the fourth quarter of fiscal year 2014. Surface revenue increased 65% to\n$3.6 billion, primarily due to Surface Pro 3 units sold. Surface Pro 3 was released in June 2014.']

['', '\x95', '', 'Search advertising revenue increased $651 million or 22%, primarily driven by growth in Bing, due to higher revenue per search and search volume.']

Table:
['', '\x95', '', 'Gaming revenue increased $463 million or 5%, mainly due to growth in Xbox Live and video games revenue, offset in part by a decrease in Xbox hardware revenue\nand third-party video game royalties. We sold 12.1\xa0million Xbox consoles in fiscal year 2015 compared with 11.7\xa0million consoles in fiscal year 2014. Xbox Live revenue increased $500 million, driven by increased Xbox Live users and revenue\nper user. Video games revenue increased $265 million, mainly due to sales of Minecraft following the acquisition of Mojang in November 2014, and new Xbox titles released in the current year.']

['', '\x95', '', 'Windows revenue decreased $3.6 billion or 16%, mainly due to lower revenue from Windows OEM and Windows Phone. Windows OEM Pro revenue decreased, primarily due to benefits realized from the expiration of support for Windows XP in the prior year, and declines in the']

Table:
['', 'business PC market. Windows OEM non-Pro revenue declined, mainly due to an increased mix of opening price point devices sold, and declines in the consumer PC market. Table:
['', '\x95', '', 'Level 1 \x96 inputs are based upon unadjusted quoted prices for identical instruments traded in active markets. Our Level 1 non-derivative\ninvestments primarily include U.S. government securities, domestic and international equities, and actively traded mutual funds.\xa0Our Level 1 derivative assets and liabilities include those actively traded on exchanges.']

Table:
['', '\x95', '', 'Level 2 \x96 inputs are based upon quoted prices for similar instruments in active markets, quoted prices for identical or similar instruments in\nmarkets that are not active, and model-based valuation techniques (e.g. the Black-Scholes model) for which all significant inputs are observable in the market or can be corroborated by observable market data for substantially the full term of the\nassets or liabilities. Where applicable, these models project future cash flows and discount the future amounts to a present value using market-based observable inputs including interest rate curves, credit spreads, foreign exchange rates, and\nforward and spot prices for currencies and commodities. Our Level 2 non-derivative investments consist primarily of corporate notes and bonds, common and preferred stock, mortgage- and asset-backed securities, U.S. government and agency securities,\nand foreign government bonds. Our Level 2 derivative assets and liabilities primarily include certain over-the-counter option and swap contracts.']

Table:
['', '\x95', '', 'Level 3 \x96 inputs are generally unobservable and typically reflect management\x92s estimates of assumptions that market participants would use in\npricing the asset or liability. The fair values are therefore determined using model-based techniques, including option pricing models and discounted cash flow models. Our Level 3 non-derivative assets primarily comprise investments in common and\npreferred stock, and goodwill and intangible assets, when they are recorded at fair value due to an impairment charge.\xa0Unobservable inputs used in the models are significant to the fair values of the assets and liabilities.']

['- DefinitionAmount of currency on hand as well as demand deposits with banks or financial institutions. Includes other kinds of accounts that have the general characteristics of demand deposits. Also includes short-term, highly liquid investments that are both readily convertible to known amounts of cash and so near their maturity that they present insignificant risk of changes in value because of changes in interest rates. ['- DefinitionCash includes currency on hand as well as demand deposits with banks or financial institutions. It also includes other kinds of accounts that have the general characteristics of demand deposits in that the customer may deposit additional funds at any time and effectively may withdraw funds at any time without prior notice or penalty. Cash equivalents, excluding items classified as marketable securities, include short-term, highly liquid Investments that are both readily convertible to known amounts of cash, and so near their maturity that they present minimal risk of changes in value because of changes in interest rates. Generally, only investments with original maturities of three months or less qualify under that definition. Original maturity means original maturity to the entity holding the investment. For example, both a three-month US Treasury bill and a three-year Treasury note purchased three months from maturity qualify as cash equivalents. However, a Treasury note purchased three years ago does not become a cash equivalent when its remaining maturity is three months. Short-term investments, exclusive of cash equivalents, generally consist of marketable securities intended to be sold within one year (or the normal operating cycle if longer) and may include trading securities, available-for-sale securities, or held-to-maturity securities (if maturing within one year), as applicable.\n+ ReferencesReference 1: http://www.xbrl.org/2003/role/presentationRef -Publisher FASB -Name Accounting Standards Codification -Glossary Cash Equivalents -URI http://asc.fasb.org/extlink&oid=6507016Reference 2: http://www.xbrl.org/2003/role/presentationRef -Publisher FASB -Name Accounting Standards Codification -Glossary Cash -URI http://asc.fasb.org/extlink&oid=6506951Reference 3: http://www.xbrl.org/2003/role/presentationRef -Publisher FASB -Name Accounting Standards Codification -Topic 210 -SubTopic 10 -Section S99 -Paragraph 1 -Subparagraph (SX 210.5-02.1) -URI http://asc.fasb.org/extlink&oid=6877327&loc=d3e13212-122682\n+ Details\n\n Name:\nus-gaap_CashCashEquivalentsAndShortTermInvestments\n\n\n Namespace Prefix:\nus-gaap_\n\n\n Data Type:\nxbrli:monetaryItemType\n\n\n Balance Type:\ndebit\n\n\n Period Type:\ninstant', 'Name:', 'us-gaap_CashCashEquivalentsAndShortTermInvestments', 'Namespace Prefix:', 'us-gaap_', 'Data Type:', 'xbrli:monetaryItemType', 'Balance Type:', 'debit', 'Period Type:', 'instant']

['- DefinitionThe noncurrent portion of deferred revenue amount as of balance sheet date. Deferred revenue is a liability related to a revenue producing activity for which revenue has not yet been recognized, and is not expected to be recognized in the next twelve months. Generally, an entity records deferred revenue when it receives consideration from a customer before achieving certain criteria that must be met for revenue to be recognized in conformity with GAAP.\n+ ['[1]\nOf the 175 million shares repurchased in fiscal year 2014, 128 million shares were repurchased for $4.9 billion under the share repurchase program approved by our Board of Directors on September 16, 2013 and 47 million shares were repurchased for $1.5 billion under the share repurchase program that was announced on September 22, 2008 and expired on September 30, 2013.\n\n\n[2]\nIncludes $7.5 billion of goodwill and asset impairment charges related to our phone business, and $2.5 billion of integration and restructuring expenses, primarily associated with our Phone Hardware Integration Plan and Phone Hardware Restructuring Plan, which together decreased net income and diluted EPS by $9.5 billion and $1.15, respectively.\n\n\n[3]\nIncludes $630 million of asset impairment charges related to our phone business, and $480 million of restructuring charges associated with our 2016 restructuring plans, which together decreased net income and diluted EPS by $895 million and $0.11, respectively.', '[1]', 'Of the 175 million shares repurchased in fiscal year 2014, 128 million shares were repurchased for $4.9 billion under the share repurchase program approved by our Board of Directors on September 16, 2013 and 47 million shares were repurchased for $1.5 billion under the share repurchase program that was announced on September 22, 2008 and expired on September 30, 2013.', '[2]', 'Includes $7.5 billion of goodwill and asset impairment charges related to our phone business, and $2.5 billion of integration and restructuring expenses, primarily associated with our Phone Hardware Integration Plan and Phone Hardware Restructuring Plan, which together decreased net income and diluted EPS by $9.5 billion and $1.15, respectively.', '[3]', 'Includes $630 million of asset impairment charges related to our phone business, and $480 million of restructuring charges associated with our 2016 restructuring plans, which together decreased net income and diluted EPS by $895 million and $0.11, respectively.']
['[1]', 'Of the 175 million shares repurchased in fiscal year 2014, 128 million shares were repurchased for $4.9 billion under the share repurchase program approved by our Board of Directors on September 16, 2013 and 47 million shares were repurchased for $1.5 billion under the share repurchase program that was announced on September 22, 2008 and expired on September 30, 2013.']
['[2]', 'Includes $7.5 billion of goodwill and asset impairment charges related to our phone business, and $2.5 billion of integration and restructuring expenses, primarily associated with our Phone Hardware Integration Plan and Phone Hardware Restructuring Plan, which together decreased net income and diluted EPS by $9.5 billion and $1.15, respectively.']
['[3]', 'Includes $630 million of asset impairment charges related to our phone business, and $480 million of restructuring charges associated with our 2016 restructuring plans, which together decreased net income and diluted EPS by $895 million and $0.11, respectively.']

Table:
['[1]', 'Of the 175 million shares repurchased in fiscal year 2014, 128 million shares were repurchased for $4.9 billion under the share repurchase program approved by our Board of Directors on September 16, 2013 and 47 million shares were repurchased for $1.5 billion under the share repurchase program that was announced on September 22, 2008 and expired on September 30, 2013.']
['[2]', 'Includes $7.5 billion of goodwill and asset impairment charges related to our phone business, and $2.5 billion of integration and restructuring expenses, primarily associated with our Phone Hardware Integration Plan and Phone Hardware Restructuring Plan, which together decreased net income and diluted EPS by $9.5 billion and $1.15, respectively.']
['[3]', 'Includes $630 million of asset impairment charges related to our phone business, and $480 million of restructuring charges associated with our 2016 restructuring plans, which together decreased net income and diluted EPS by $895 million and $0.11, respectively.']

["- DefinitionTotal of all stockholders' equity (deficit) items, net of receivables from officers, directors, owners, and affiliates of the entity which are attributable to the parent. The amount of the economic entity's stockholders' equity attributable to the parent excludes the amount of stockholders' equity which is allocable to that ownership interest in subsidiary equity which is not attributable to the parent (noncontrolling interest, minority interest). ['ACCOUNTING POLICIES', '12 Months Ended']
['Jun. 30, 2016']
['ACCOUNTING POLICIES', 'NOTE 1\n — ACCOUNTING POLICIES\n\nAccounting\n Principles\nThe\n consolidated financial statements and accompanying notes are\n prepared in accordance with accounting principles generally\n accepted in the United States of America (“U.S.\n GAAP”).\nWe have\n recast certain prior period amounts to conform to the current\n period presentation, with no impact on consolidated net income or\n cash flows.\n\nPrinciples of\n Consolidation\nThe\n consolidated financial statements include the accounts of Microsoft\n Corporation and its subsidiaries. Intercompany transactions and\n balances have been eliminated. Equity investments through which we\n are able to exercise significant influence over but do not control\n the investee and are not the primary beneficiary of the\n investee’s activities are accounted for using the equity\n method. Investments through which we are not able to exercise\n significant influence over the investee and which do not have\n readily determinable fair values are accounted for under the cost\n method.\n\nSegment\n Information\nIn June\n 2015, we announced a change in organizational structure to align to\n our strategic direction as a productivity and platform company.\n During the first quarter of fiscal year 2016, our chief operating\n decision maker, who is also our Chief Executive Officer, requested\n changes in the information that he regularly reviews for purposes\n of allocating resources and assessing performance. As a result,\n beginning in fiscal year 2016, we report our financial performance\n based on our new segments described in Note 21 – Segment\n Information and Geographic Data. We have recast certain prior\n period amounts to conform to the way we internally manage and\n monitor segment performance during fiscal year 2016. This change\n primarily impacted Note 10 – Goodwill, Note 15 –\n Unearned Revenue, and Note 21 – Segment Information and\n Geographic Data, with no impact on consolidated net income or cash\n flows.\n\nEstimates and\n Assumptions\nPreparing\n financial statements requires management to make estimates and\n assumptions that affect the reported amounts of assets,\n liabilities, revenue, and expenses. Examples of estimates include:\n loss contingencies; product warranties; the fair value of, and/or\n potential impairment of goodwill and intangible assets, for our\n reporting units; product life cycles; useful lives of our tangible\n and intangible assets; allowances for doubtful accounts; allowances\n for product returns; the market value of and volume of demand for\n our inventory; and stock-based compensation forfeiture rates.\n Examples of assumptions include: the elements comprising a software\n arrangement, including the distinction between upgrades or\n enhancements and new products; when technological feasibility is\n achieved for our products; the potential outcome of future tax\n consequences of events that have been recognized on our\n consolidated financial statements or tax returns; and determining\n when investment impairments are other-than-temporary. Actual\n results and outcomes may differ from management’s estimates\n and assumptions.\n\nForeign\n Currencies\nAssets\n and liabilities recorded in foreign currencies are translated at\n the exchange rate on the balance sheet date. Revenue and expenses\n are translated at average rates of exchange prevailing during the\n year. Translation adjustments resulting from this process are\n recorded to other comprehensive income\n (“OCI”).\n\n \xa0\n\nProduct Revenue and\n Service and Other Revenue\nService\n revenue exceeded 10% of total revenue for the first time in fiscal\n year 2016. As a result, we have separately disclosed product\n revenue and service and other revenue on our consolidated income\n statements.\nProduct\n revenue includes sales from operating systems; cross-device\n productivity applications; server applications; business solution\n applications; desktop and server management tools; software\n development tools; video games; hardware such as PCs, tablets,\n gaming and entertainment consoles, phones, other intelligent\n devices, and related accessories; and training and certification of\n computer system integrators and developers.\nService\n and other revenue includes sales from cloud-based solutions that\n provide customers with software, services, platforms, and content\n such as Office 365, Microsoft Azure (“Azure”),\n Microsoft Dynamics (“Dynamics”) CRM Online, and Xbox\n Live; solution support; and consulting services. Service and other\n revenue also includes sales from online advertising.\n\nRevenue\n Recognition\nRevenue\n is recognized when persuasive evidence of an arrangement exists,\n delivery has occurred, the fee is fixed or determinable, and\n collectability is probable. Revenue generally is recognized net of\n allowances for returns and any taxes collected from customers and\n subsequently remitted to governmental authorities.\nRevenue\n recognition for multiple-element arrangements requires judgment to\n determine if multiple elements exist, whether elements can be\n accounted for as separate units of accounting, and if so, the fair\n value for each of the elements.\nMicrosoft\n enters into arrangements that can include various combinations of\n software, services, and hardware. Where elements are delivered over\n different periods of time, and when allowed under U.S. GAAP,\n revenue is allocated to the respective elements based on their\n relative selling prices at the inception of the arrangement, and\n revenue is recognized as each element is delivered. We use a\n hierarchy to determine the fair value to be used for allocating\n revenue to elements: (i)\xa0vendor-specific objective evidence of\n fair value (“VSOE”), (ii)\xa0third-party evidence,\n and (iii)\xa0best estimate of selling price (“ESP”).\n For software elements, we follow the industry specific software\n guidance which only allows for the use of VSOE in establishing fair\n value. Generally, VSOE is the price charged when the deliverable is\n sold separately or the price established by management for a\n product that is not yet sold if it is probable that the price will\n not change before introduction into the marketplace. ESPs are\n established as best estimates of what the selling prices would be\n if the deliverables were sold regularly on a stand-alone basis. Our\n process for determining ESPs requires judgment and considers\n multiple factors that may vary over time depending upon the unique\n facts and circumstances related to each deliverable.\nRevenue\n for retail packaged products, products licensed to original\n equipment manufacturers (“OEMs”), and perpetual\n licenses under certain volume licensing programs generally is\n recognized as products are shipped or made available.\nTechnology guarantee programs are accounted for as\n multiple-element arrangements as customers receive free or\n significantly discounted rights to use upcoming new versions of a\n software product if they license existing versions of the product\n during the eligibility period. Revenue is allocated between the\n existing product and the new product, and revenue allocated to the\n new product is deferred until that version is delivered. The\n revenue allocation is based on the VSOE of fair value of the\n products. The VSOE of fair value for upcoming new products are\n based on the price determined by management having the relevant\n authority when the element is not yet sold separately, but is\n expected to be sold in the near future at the price set by\n management.\nSoftware\n updates that will be provided free of charge are evaluated on a\n case-by-case basis to determine whether they meet the definition of\n an upgrade and create a multiple-element arrangement, which may\n require revenue to be deferred and recognized when the upgrade is\n delivered, or if it is determined that implied post-contract\n customer support (“PCS”) is being provided, the\n arrangement is accounted for as a multiple-element arrangement and\n all revenue from the arrangement is deferred and recognized over\n the implied PCS term when the VSOE of fair value does not exist. If\n updates are determined to not meet the definition of an upgrade,\n revenue is generally recognized as products are shipped or made\n available.\nCustomers\n purchasing a Windows 10 license will receive unspecified updates\n and upgrades over the life of their Windows 10 device at no\n additional cost. As these updates and upgrades will not be sold on\n a stand-alone basis, we are unable to establish VSOE of fair value.\n Accordingly, revenue from licenses of Windows 10 is recognized\n ratably over the estimated life of the related device, which ranges\n between two to four years.\nCertain\n volume licensing arrangements include a perpetual license for\n current products combined with rights to receive unspecified future\n versions of software products, which we have determined are\n additional software products and are therefore accounted for as\n subscriptions, with billings recorded as unearned revenue and\n recognized as revenue ratably over the coverage period.\n Arrangements that include term-based licenses for current products\n with the right to use unspecified future versions of the software\n during the coverage period, are also accounted for as\n subscriptions, with revenue recognized ratably over the coverage\n period. Revenue from cloud-based services arrangements that allow\n for the use of a hosted software product or service over a\n contractually determined period of time without taking possession\n of software are accounted for as subscriptions with billings\n recorded as unearned revenue and recognized as revenue ratably over\n the coverage period beginning on the date the service is made\n available to customers. Revenue from cloud-based services\n arrangements that are provided on a consumption basis (for example,\n the amount of storage used in a particular period) is recognized\n commensurate with the customer utilization of such\n resources.\nSome\n volume licensing arrangements include time-based subscriptions for\n cloud-based services and software offerings that are accounted for\n as subscriptions. These arrangements are considered\n multiple-element arrangements. However, because all elements are\n accounted for as subscriptions and have the same coverage period\n and delivery pattern, they have the same revenue recognition\n timing.\nRevenue\n related to Microsoft Surface (“Surface”) devices, Xbox\n consoles, games published by us, phones, and other hardware\n components is generally recognized when ownership is transferred to\n the resellers or to end customers when selling directly through\n Microsoft retail stores and online marketplaces. A portion of\n revenue may be deferred when these products are combined with\n software elements, and/or services. Revenue related to licensing\n for games published by third parties for use on the Xbox consoles\n is recognized when games are manufactured by the game\n publishers.\nDisplay\n advertising revenue is recognized as advertisements are displayed.\n Search advertising revenue is recognized when the ad appears in the\n search results or when the action necessary to earn the revenue has\n been completed. Consulting services revenue is recognized as\n services are rendered, generally based on the negotiated hourly\n rate in the consulting arrangement and the number of hours worked\n during the period. Consulting revenue for fixed-price services\n arrangements is recognized as services are provided.\n\nCost of\n Revenue\nCost of\n revenue includes: manufacturing and distribution costs for products\n sold and programs licensed; operating costs related to product\n support service centers and product distribution centers; costs\n incurred to include software on PCs sold by OEMs, to drive traffic\n to our websites, and to acquire online advertising space; costs\n incurred to support and maintain Internet-based products and\n services, including datacenter costs and royalties; warranty costs;\n inventory valuation adjustments; costs associated with the delivery\n of consulting services; and the amortization of capitalized\n software development costs. Capitalized software development costs\n are amortized over the estimated lives of the products.\n\nProduct\n Warranty\nWe\n provide for the estimated costs of fulfilling our obligations under\n hardware and software warranties at the time the related revenue is\n recognized. For hardware warranties, we estimate the costs based on\n historical and projected product failure rates, historical and\n projected repair costs, and knowledge of specific product failures\n (if any). The specific hardware warranty terms and conditions vary\n depending upon the product sold and the country in which we do\n business, but generally include parts and labor over a period\n generally ranging from 90\xa0days to three years. For software\n warranties, we estimate the costs to provide bug fixes, such as\n security patches, over the estimated life of the software. We\n regularly reevaluate our estimates to assess the adequacy of the\n recorded warranty liabilities and adjust the amounts as\n necessary.\n\nResearch and\n Development\nResearch\n and development expenses include payroll, employee benefits,\n stock-based compensation expense, and other headcount-related\n expenses associated with product development. Research and\n development expenses also include third-party development and\n programming costs, localization costs incurred to translate\n software for international markets, and the amortization of\n purchased software code and services content. Such costs related to\n software development are included in research and development\n expense until the point that technological feasibility is reached,\n which for our software products, is generally shortly before the\n products are released to manufacturing. Once technological\n feasibility is reached, such costs are capitalized and amortized to\n cost of revenue over the estimated lives of the\n products.\n\nSales and\n Marketing\nSales and\n marketing expenses include payroll, employee benefits, stock-based\n compensation expense, and other headcount-related expenses\n associated with sales and marketing personnel, and the costs of\n advertising, promotions, trade shows, seminars, and other programs.\n Advertising costs are expensed as incurred. Advertising expense was\n $1.6 billion, $1.9 billion, and $2.3 billion in fiscal years 2016,\n 2015, and 2014, respectively.\n\nStock-Based\n Compensation\nCompensation cost for stock awards is measured at the fair\n value on the grant date and recognized as expense, net of estimated\n forfeitures, over the related service period using the\n straight-line method. The fair value of stock awards is based on\n the quoted price of our common stock on the grant date less the\n present value of expected dividends not received during the vesting\n period. Compensation expense for the employee stock purchase plan\n (“ESPP”) is measured as the discount the employee is\n entitled to upon purchase and is recognized in the period of\n purchase.\n\nIncome\n Taxes\nIncome\n tax expense includes U.S. and international income taxes, the\n provision for U.S. taxes on undistributed earnings of international\n subsidiaries not deemed to be permanently reinvested, and interest\n and penalties on uncertain tax positions. Certain income and\n expenses are not reported in tax returns and financial statements\n in the same year. The tax effect of such temporary differences is\n reported as deferred income taxes. Deferred tax assets are reported\n net of a valuation allowance when it is more likely than not that a\n tax benefit will not be realized. All deferred income taxes are\n classified as long-term on our consolidated balance\n sheets.\n\nFair Value\n Measurements\nWe\n account for certain assets and liabilities at fair value. The\n hierarchy below lists three levels of fair value based on the\n extent to which inputs used in measuring fair value are observable\n in the market.\xa0We categorize each of our fair value\n measurements in one of these three levels based on the lowest level\n input that is significant to the fair value measurement in its\n entirety. These levels are:\n\n \xa0\n\n\n\xa0\n•\n\xa0\n\nLevel 1\xa0– inputs are based upon\n unadjusted quoted prices for identical instruments traded in active\n markets. Our Level 1 non-derivative investments primarily include\n U.S. government securities, domestic and international equities,\n and actively traded mutual funds.\xa0Our Level 1 derivative\n assets and liabilities include those actively traded on\n exchanges.\n\n\n\n\n \xa0\n\n\n\xa0\n•\n\xa0\n\nLevel 2\xa0– inputs are based upon\n quoted prices for similar instruments in active markets, quoted\n prices for identical or similar instruments in markets that are not\n active, and model-based valuation techniques (e.g. the\n Black-Scholes model) for which all significant inputs are\n observable in the market or can be corroborated by observable\n market data for substantially the full term of the assets or\n liabilities. Where applicable, these models project future cash\n flows and discount the future amounts to a present value using\n market-based observable inputs including interest rate curves,\n credit spreads, foreign exchange rates, and forward and spot prices\n for currencies and commodities. Our Level 2 non-derivative\n investments consist primarily of corporate notes and bonds, common\n and preferred stock, mortgage- and asset-backed securities, U.S.\n government and agency securities, and foreign government bonds. Our\n Level 2 derivative assets and liabilities primarily include certain\n over-the-counter option and swap contracts.\n\n\n\n\n \xa0\n\n\n\xa0\n•\n\xa0\n\nLevel 3\xa0– inputs are generally\n unobservable and typically reflect management’s estimates of\n assumptions that market participants would use in pricing the asset\n or liability. The fair values are therefore determined using\n model-based techniques, including option pricing models and\n discounted cash flow models. Our Level 3 non-derivative assets\n primarily comprise investments in common and preferred stock, and\n goodwill and intangible assets, when they are recorded at fair\n value due to an impairment charge.\xa0Unobservable inputs used in\n the models are significant to the fair values of the assets and\n liabilities.\n\n\n\nWe\n measure certain assets, including our cost and equity method\n investments, at fair value on a nonrecurring basis when they are\n deemed to be other-than-temporarily impaired. The fair values of\n these investments are determined based on valuation techniques\n using the best information available, and may include quoted market\n prices, market comparables, and discounted cash flow projections.\n An impairment charge is recorded when the cost of the investment\n exceeds its fair value and this condition is determined to be\n other-than-temporary.\nOur other\n current financial assets and our current financial liabilities have\n fair values that approximate their carrying values.\n\nFinancial\n Instruments\n\nInvestments\nWe\n consider all highly liquid interest-earning investments with a\n maturity of three months or less at the date of purchase to be cash\n equivalents. The fair values of these investments approximate their\n carrying values. In general, investments with original maturities\n of greater than three months and remaining maturities of less than\n one year are classified as short-term investments. Investments with\n maturities beyond one year may be classified as short-term based on\n their highly liquid nature and because such marketable securities\n represent the investment of cash that is available for current\n operations. All cash equivalents and short-term investments are\n classified as available-for-sale and realized gains and losses are\n recorded using the specific identification method. Changes in\n market value, excluding other-than-temporary impairments, are\n reflected in OCI.\nEquity\n and other investments classified as long-term include both debt and\n equity instruments. Debt and publicly-traded equity securities are\n classified as available-for-sale and realized gains and losses are\n recorded using the specific identification method. Changes in the\n market value of available-for-sale securities, excluding\n other-than-temporary impairments, are reflected in OCI. Common and\n preferred stock and other investments that are restricted for more\n than one year or are not publicly traded are recorded at cost or\n using the equity method.\nWe lend\n certain fixed-income and equity securities to increase investment\n returns. These transactions are accounted for as secured borrowings\n and the loaned securities continue to be carried as investments on\n our consolidated balance sheets. Cash and/or security interests are\n received as collateral for the loaned securities with the amount\n determined based upon the underlying security lent and the\n creditworthiness of the borrower. Cash received is recorded as an\n asset with a corresponding liability.\nInvestments are considered to be impaired when a decline in\n fair value is judged to be other-than-temporary. Fair value is\n calculated based on publicly available market information or other\n estimates determined by management. We employ a systematic\n methodology on a quarterly basis that considers available\n quantitative and qualitative evidence in evaluating potential\n impairment of our investments. If the cost of an investment exceeds\n its fair value, we evaluate, among other factors, general market\n conditions, credit quality of debt instrument issuers, the duration\n and extent to which the fair value is less than cost, and for\n equity securities, our intent and ability to hold, or plans to\n sell, the investment. For fixed-income securities, we also evaluate\n whether we have plans to sell the security or it is more likely\n than not that we will be required to sell the security before\n recovery. We also consider specific adverse conditions related to\n the financial health of and business outlook for the investee,\n including industry and sector performance, changes in technology,\n and operational and financing cash flow factors. Once a decline in\n fair value is determined to be other-than-temporary, an impairment\n charge is recorded to other income (expense), net and a new cost\n basis in the investment is established.\n\nDerivatives\nDerivative instruments are recognized as either assets or\n liabilities and are measured at fair value. The accounting for\n changes in the fair value of a derivative depends on the intended\n use of the derivative and the resulting designation.\nFor\n derivative instruments designated as fair value hedges, the gains\n (losses) are recognized in earnings in the periods of change\n together with the offsetting losses (gains) on the hedged items\n attributed to the risk being hedged. For options designated as fair\n value hedges, changes in the time value are excluded from the\n assessment of hedge effectiveness and are recognized in\n earnings.\nFor\n derivative instruments designated as cash flow hedges, the\n effective portion of the gains (losses) on the derivatives is\n initially reported as a component of OCI and is subsequently\n recognized in earnings when the hedged exposure is recognized in\n earnings. For options designated as cash flow hedges, changes in\n the time value are excluded from the assessment of hedge\n effectiveness and are recognized in earnings. Gains (losses) on\n derivatives representing either hedge components excluded from the\n assessment of effectiveness or hedge ineffectiveness are recognized\n in earnings.\nFor\n derivative instruments that are not designated as hedges, gains\n (losses) from changes in fair values are primarily recognized in\n other income (expense), net. Other than those derivatives entered\n into for investment purposes, such as commodity contracts, the\n gains (losses) are generally economically offset by unrealized\n gains (losses) in the underlying available-for-sale securities,\n which are recorded as a component of OCI until the securities are\n sold or other-than-temporarily impaired, at which time the amounts\n are reclassified from accumulated other comprehensive income\n (“AOCI”) into other income (expense), net.\n\nAllowance for Doubtful\n Accounts\nThe\n allowance for doubtful accounts reflects our best estimate of\n probable losses inherent in the accounts receivable balance. We\n determine the allowance based on known troubled accounts,\n historical experience, and other currently available evidence.\n Activity in the allowance for doubtful accounts was as\n follows:\n\n \xa0\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n(In millions)\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nYear Ended June\xa030,\n\xa0\xa0\n2016\n\xa0\n\xa0\n2015\n\xa0\n\xa0\n2014\n\xa0\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nBalance, beginning of\n period\n\n\xa0\xa0\n$\n\xa0\xa0335\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n$\n\xa0\xa0301\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n$\n\xa0\xa0336\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\nCharged to costs and other\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n146\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n77\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n16\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\nWrite-offs\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n(55\n)\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n(43\n)\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n(51\n)\xa0\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nBalance, end of period\n\n\xa0\xa0\n$\n426\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n$\n335\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n$\n301\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nInventories\nInventories are stated at average cost, subject to the lower of\n cost or market. Cost includes materials, labor, and manufacturing\n overhead related to the purchase and production of inventories. We\n regularly review inventory quantities on hand, future purchase\n commitments with our suppliers, and the estimated utility of our\n inventory. If our review indicates a reduction in utility below\n carrying value, we reduce our inventory to a new cost basis through\n a charge to cost of revenue.\n\nProperty and\n Equipment\nProperty\n and equipment is stated at cost less accumulated depreciation, and\n depreciated using the straight-line method over the shorter of the\n estimated useful life of the asset or the lease term. The estimated\n useful lives of our property and equipment are generally as\n follows: computer software developed or acquired for internal use,\n three to seven years; computer equipment, two to three years;\n buildings and improvements, five to 15 years; leasehold\n improvements, three to 20 years; and furniture and equipment, one\n to 10 years. Land is not depreciated.\n\nGoodwill\nGoodwill\n is tested for impairment at the reporting unit level (operating\n segment or one level below an operating segment) on an annual basis\n (May 1 for us) and between annual tests if an event occurs or\n circumstances change that would more likely than not reduce the\n fair value of a reporting unit below its carrying value.\n\nIntangible\n Assets\nAll of\n our intangible assets are subject to amortization and are amortized\n using the straight-line method over their estimated period of\n benefit, ranging from one to 15 years. We evaluate the\n recoverability of intangible assets periodically by taking into\n account events or circumstances that may warrant revised estimates\n of useful lives or that indicate the asset may be\n impaired.\n\nRecent Accounting\n Guidance\n\nRecently adopted\n accounting guidance\n\nImprovements to\n Employee Share-Based Payment Accounting\nIn March\n 2016, the Financial Accounting Standards Board (“FASB”)\n issued a new standard that changes the accounting for certain\n aspects of share-based payments to employees. The new guidance\n requires excess tax benefits and tax deficiencies to be recorded in\n the income statement when stock awards vest or are settled. In\n addition, cash flows related to excess tax benefits will no longer\n be separately classified as a financing activity apart from other\n income tax cash flows. The standard also allows us to repurchase\n more of an employee’s vesting shares for tax withholding\n purposes without triggering liability accounting, clarifies that\n all cash payments made to tax authorities on an employee’s\n behalf for withheld shares should be presented as a financing\n activity on our cash flows statement, and provides an accounting\n policy election to account for forfeitures as they occur. The new\n standard is effective for us beginning July\xa01, 2017, with\n early adoption permitted.\nWe\n elected to early adopt the new guidance in the third quarter of\n fiscal year 2016 which requires us to reflect any adjustments as of\n July\xa01, 2015, the beginning of the annual period that includes\n the interim period of adoption. The primary impact of adoption was\n the recognition of excess tax benefits in our provision for income\n taxes rather than paid-in capital for all periods in fiscal year\n 2016.\xa0Additional amendments to the accounting for income taxes\n and minimum statutory withholding tax requirements had no impact to\n retained earnings as of July\xa01, 2015, where the cumulative\n effect of these changes are required to be recorded. We have\n elected to continue to estimate forfeitures expected to occur to\n determine the amount of compensation cost to be recognized in each\n period.\nWe\n elected to apply the presentation requirements for cash flows\n related to excess tax benefits retrospectively to all periods\n presented which resulted in an increase to both net cash from\n operations and net cash used in financing of $588 million and $271\n million for the years ended June\xa030, 2015 and 2014,\n respectively. The presentation requirements for cash flows related\n to employee taxes paid for withheld shares had no impact to any of\n the periods presented on our consolidated cash flows statements\n since such cash flows have historically been presented as a\n financing activity.\n\n \xa0\nAdoption\n of the new standard resulted in the recognition of excess tax\n benefits in our provision for income taxes rather than paid-in\n capital of $402 million for the year ended June\xa030,\n 2016.\n\nBalance Sheet\n Classification of Deferred Taxes\nIn\n November 2015, the FASB issued guidance that requires companies to\n classify all deferred tax assets and liabilities as noncurrent on\n the balance sheet rather than separately disclosing deferred taxes\n as current and noncurrent. This standard is effective for us\n beginning July\xa01, 2017, and can be early adopted and applied\n either prospectively or retrospectively to all periods presented\n upon adoption.\nWe\n elected to early adopt the new guidance in the fourth quarter of\n fiscal year 2016 on a retrospective basis. While the guidance\n changes the manner in which deferred taxes are classified on the\n balance sheet, we are still required to offset deferred tax assets\n and liabilities for each taxpaying component within a tax\n jurisdiction. Adoption of the new standard impacted our previously\n reported results as follows:\n\n \xa0\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n(In millions)\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\nJune\xa030,\n\n2015\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n \xa0\nAs\n adjusted\n\xa0\xa0\n \xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n \xa0\nAs\n reported\n\xa0\xa0\n \xa0\xa0\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nBalance sheets:\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nCurrent deferred income tax\n assets\n\n\xa0\xa0\n$\n0\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n$\n1,915\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\nOther long-term assets\n\n\xa0\xa0\n$\n3,117\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n$\n2,953\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\nOther current liabilities\n\n\xa0\xa0\n$\n6,555\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n$\n6,766\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\nLong-term deferred income tax\n liabilities\n\n\xa0\xa0\n$\n\xa0\xa01,295\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n$\n\xa0\xa02,835\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nRecent accounting\n guidance not yet adopted\n\nFinancial Instruments\n – Credit Losses\nIn June\n 2016, the FASB issued a new standard to replace the incurred loss\n impairment methodology in current GAAP with a methodology that\n reflects expected credit losses and requires consideration of a\n broader range of reasonable and supportable information to inform\n credit loss estimates. For trade and other receivables, loans, and\n other financial instruments, we will be required to use a\n forward-looking expected loss model rather than the incurred loss\n model for recognizing credit losses which reflects losses that are\n probable. Credit losses relating to available-for-sale debt\n securities will also be recorded through an allowance for credit\n losses rather than as a reduction in the amortized cost basis of\n the securities. The new standard will be effective for us beginning\n July\xa01, 2020, with early adoption permitted beginning\n July\xa01, 2019. Application of the amendments is through a\n cumulative-effect adjustment to retained earnings as of the\n effective date. We are currently evaluating the impact of this\n standard on our consolidated financial statements.\n\nLeases\nIn\n February 2016, the FASB issued a new standard related to leases to\n increase transparency and comparability among organizations by\n requiring the recognition of lease assets and lease liabilities on\n the balance sheet. Most prominent among the amendments is the\n recognition of assets and liabilities by lessees for those leases\n classified as operating leases under previous U.S. GAAP. Under the\n new standard, disclosures are required to meet the objective of\n enabling users of financial statements to assess the amount,\n timing, and uncertainty of cash flows arising from leases. We will\n be required to recognize and measure leases at the beginning of the\n earliest period presented using a modified retrospective\n approach.\nThe new\n standard will be effective for us beginning July\xa01, 2019, with\n early adoption permitted. We currently anticipate early adoption of\n the new standard effective July\xa01, 2017 in conjunction with\n our adoption of the new revenue standard.\xa0Our ability to early\n adopt is dependent on system readiness, including software procured\n from third-party providers, and the completion of our analysis of\n information necessary to restate prior period financial\n statements.\n\n \xa0\nWe\n anticipate this standard will have a material impact on our\n consolidated financial statements. While we are continuing to\n assess all potential impacts of the standard, we currently believe\n the most significant impact relates to our accounting for office,\n retail, and datacenter operating leases.\n\nFinancial Instruments\n – Recognition, Measurement, Presentation, and\n Disclosure\nIn\n January 2016, the FASB issued a new standard to amend certain\n aspects of recognition, measurement, presentation, and disclosure\n of financial instruments. Most prominent among the amendments is\n the requirement for changes in the fair value of our equity\n investments, with certain exceptions, to be recognized through net\n income rather than OCI. The new standard will be effective for us\n beginning July\xa01, 2018. The application of the amendments will\n result in a cumulative-effect adjustment to our consolidated\n balance sheets as of the effective date. We are currently\n evaluating the impact of this standard on our consolidated\n financial statements.\n\nRevenue from Contracts\n with Customers\nIn May\n 2014, the FASB issued a new standard related to revenue\n recognition. Under the new standard, revenue is recognized when a\n customer obtains control of promised goods or services and is\n recognized in an amount that reflects the consideration which the\n entity expects to receive in exchange for those goods or services.\n In addition, the standard requires disclosure of the nature,\n amount, timing, and uncertainty of revenue and cash flows arising\n from contracts with customers. The FASB has recently issued several\n amendments to the standard, including clarification on accounting\n for licenses of intellectual property and identifying performance\n obligations.\nThe\n guidance permits two methods of adoption: retrospectively to each\n prior reporting period presented (full retrospective method), or\n retrospectively with the cumulative effect of initially applying\n the guidance recognized at the date of initial application (the\n cumulative catch-up transition method). We currently anticipate\n adopting the standard using the full retrospective method to\n restate each prior reporting period presented.\nThe new\n standard will be effective for us beginning July\xa01, 2018, and\n adoption as of the original effective date of July\xa01, 2017 is\n permitted. We currently anticipate early adoption of the new\n standard effective July\xa01, 2017. Our ability to early adopt\n using the full retrospective method is dependent on system\n readiness, including software procured from third-party providers,\n and the completion of our analysis of information necessary to\n restate prior period financial statements.\nWe\n anticipate this standard will have a material impact on our\n consolidated financial statements. While we are continuing to\n assess all potential impacts of the standard, we currently believe\n the most significant impact relates to our accounting for software\n license revenue. We expect revenue related to hardware, cloud\n offerings, and professional services to remain substantially\n unchanged. Specifically, under the new standard we expect to\n recognize Windows 10 revenue predominantly at the time of billing\n rather than ratably over the life of the related device. We also\n expect to recognize license revenue at the time of billing rather\n than over the subscription period from certain multi-year\n commercial software subscriptions that include both software\n licenses and Software Assurance. Due to the complexity of certain\n of our commercial license subscription contracts, the actual\n revenue recognition treatment required under the standard will be\n dependent on contract-specific terms, and may vary in some\n instances from recognition at the time of billing.\nWe\n currently believe that the net change in Windows 10 revenue from\n period to period is indicative of the net change in revenue we\n expect from the adoption of the new standard.', '', '•', '', 'Level 1\xa0– inputs are based upon\n unadjusted quoted prices for identical instruments traded in active\n markets. Our Level 1 non-derivative investments primarily include\n U.S. government securities, domestic and international equities,\n and actively traded mutual funds.\xa0Our Level 1 derivative\n assets and liabilities include those actively traded on\n exchanges.', '', '•', '', 'Level 2\xa0– inputs are based upon\n quoted prices for similar instruments in active markets, quoted\n prices for identical or similar instruments in markets that are not\n active, and model-based valuation techniques (e.g. the\n Black-Scholes model) for which all significant inputs are\n observable in the market or can be corroborated by observable\n market data for substantially the full term of the assets or\n liabilities. Where applicable, these models project future cash\n flows and discount the future amounts to a present value using\n market-based observable inputs including interest rate curves,\n credit spreads, foreign exchange rates, and forward and spot prices\n for currencies and commodities. Our Level 2 non-derivative\n investments consist primarily of corporate notes and bonds, common\n and preferred stock, mortgage- and asset-backed securities, U.S.\n government and agency securities, and foreign government bonds. Our\n Level 2 derivative assets and liabilities primarily include certain\n over-the-counter option and swap contracts.', '', '•', '', 'Level 3\xa0– inputs are generally\n unobservable and typically reflect management’s estimates of\n assumptions that market participants would use in pricing the asset\n or liability. The fair values are therefore determined using\n model-based techniques, including option pricing models and\n discounted cash flow models. Our Level 3 non-derivative assets\n primarily comprise investments in common and preferred stock, and\n goodwill and intangible assets, when they are recorded at fair\n value due to an impairment charge.\xa0Unobservable inputs used in\n the models are significant to the fair values of the assets and\n liabilities.', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '(In millions)', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', 'Year Ended June\xa030,', '', '2016', '', '', '2015', '', '', '2014', '', '', '', '', '', 'Balance, beginning of\n period', '', '$', '335', '', '', '$', '301', '', '', '$', '336', '', 'Charged to costs and other', '', '', '146', '', '', '', '77', '', '', '', '16', '', 'Write-offs', '', '', '(55', ')', '', '', '(43', ')', '', '', '(51', ')', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', 'Balance, end of period', '', '$', '426', '', '', '$', '335', '', '', '$', '301', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '(In millions)', '', 'June\xa030,\n\n2015', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', 'As\n adjusted', '', '', '', 'As\n reported', '', '', '', '', 'Balance sheets:', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', 'Current deferred income tax\n assets', '', '$', '0', '', '', '$', '1,915', '', 'Other long-term assets', '', '$', '3,117', '', '', '$', '2,953', '', 'Other current liabilities', '', '$', '6,555', '', '', '$', '6,766', '', 'Long-term deferred income tax\n liabilities', '', '$', '1,295', '', '', '$', '2,835', '', '', '']
['', '•', '', 'Level 1\xa0– inputs are based upon\n unadjusted quoted prices for identical instruments traded in active\n markets. Our Level 1 non-derivative investments primarily include\n U.S. government securities, domestic and international equities,\n and actively traded mutual funds.\xa0Our Level 1 derivative\n assets and liabilities include those actively traded on\n exchanges.']
['', '•', '', 'Level 2\xa0– inputs are based upon\n quoted prices for similar instruments in active markets, quoted\n prices for identical or similar instruments in markets that are not\n active, and model-based valuation techniques (e.g. the\n Black-Scholes model) for which all significant inputs are\n observable in the market or can be corroborated by observable\n market data for substantially the full term of the assets or\n liabilities. Where applicable, these models project future cash\n flows and discount the future amounts to a present value using\n market-based observable inputs including interest rate curves,\n credit spreads, foreign exchange rates, and forward and spot prices\n for currencies and commodities. Our Level 2 non-derivative\n investments consist primarily of corporate notes and bonds, common\n and preferred stock, mortgage- and asset-backed securities, U.S.\n government and agency securities, and foreign government bonds. Our\n Level 2 derivative assets and liabilities primarily include certain\n over-the-counter option and swap contracts.']
['', '•', '', 'Level 3\xa0– inputs are generally\n unobservable and typically reflect management’s estimates of\n assumptions that market participants would use in pricing the asset\n or liability. The fair values are therefore determined using\n model-based techniques, including option pricing models and\n discounted cash flow models. Our Level 3 non-derivative assets\n primarily comprise investments in common and preferred stock, and\n goodwill and intangible assets, when they are recorded at fair\n value due to an impairment charge.\xa0Unobservable inputs used in\n the models are significant to the fair values of the assets and\n liabilities.']

['', '•', '', 'Level 2\xa0– inputs are based upon\n quoted prices for similar instruments in active markets, quoted\n prices for identical or similar instruments in markets that are not\n active, and model-based valuation techniques (e.g. the\n Black-Scholes model) for which all significant inputs are\n observable in the market or can be corroborated by observable\n market data for substantially the full term of the assets or\n liabilities. Where applicable, these models project future cash\n flows and discount the future amounts to a present value using\n market-based observable inputs including interest rate curves,\n credit spreads, foreign exchange rates, and forward and spot prices\n for currencies and commodities. Our Level 2 non-derivative\n investments consist primarily of corporate notes and bonds, common\n and preferred stock, mortgage- and asset-backed securities, U.S.\n government and agency securities, and foreign government bonds. Our\n Level 2 derivative assets and liabilities primarily include certain\n over-the-counter option and swap contracts.']

Our Level 3 non-derivative assets\n primarily comprise investments in common and preferred stock, and\n goodwill and intangible assets, when they are recorded at fair\n value due to an impairment charge.\xa0Unobservable inputs used in\n the models are significant to the fair values of the assets and\n liabilities.']

['EARNINGS PER SHARE', 'NOTE 2 —\n EARNINGS PER SHARE\n\nBasic earnings per share\n (“EPS”) is computed based on the weighted average\n number of shares of common stock outstanding during the period.\n Diluted EPS is computed based on the weighted average number of\n shares of common stock plus the effect of dilutive potential common\n shares outstanding during the period using the treasury stock\n method. Dilutive potential common shares include outstanding stock\n options and stock awards.\n\n \xa0\nThe components of basic and diluted\n EPS are as follows:\n\n ['OTHER INCOME (EXPENSE), NET', 'NOTE 3 — OTHER\n INCOME (EXPENSE), NET\nThe components of other income\n (expense), net were as follows:\n\n \xa0\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n(In millions)\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nYear Ended June\xa030,\n\xa0\xa0\n2016\n\xa0\n\xa0\n2015\n\xa0\n\xa0\n2014\n\xa0\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nDividends and interest\n income\n\n\xa0\xa0\n$\n\xa0\xa0\xa0\xa0\xa0\xa0903\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n$\n\xa0\xa0\xa0766\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n$\n\xa0\xa0\xa0883\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\nInterest expense\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n(1,243\n)\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n(781\n)\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n(597\n)\xa0\n\n\n\nNet recognized gains on\n investments\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n668\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n716\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n437\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\nNet losses on derivatives\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n(443\n)\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n(423\n)\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n(328\n)\xa0\n\n\n\nNet gains (losses) on foreign\n currency remeasurements\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n(121\n)\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n335\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n(165\n)\xa0\n\n\n\nOther\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n(195\n)\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n(267\n)\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n(169\n)\xa0\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nTotal\n\n\xa0\xa0\n$\n(431\n)\xa0\n\xa0\n$\n346\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n$\n61\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nFollowing are details of net\n recognized gains (losses) on investments during the periods\n reported:\n\n \xa0\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n(In of June\xa030, 2016\n and 2015, the recorded bases of common and preferred stock that are\n restricted for more than one year or are not publicly traded were\n $767 million and $561 million, respectively. These investments are\n carried at cost and are reviewed quarterly for indicators of\n other-than-temporary impairment. It is not practicable for us to\n reliably estimate the fair value of these investments.\n\nAs of June\xa030, 2016\n and 2015, the collateral received under agreements for loaned\n securities totaled
