['DERIVATIVES', '12 Months Ended']
['Jun. 30, 2016']
['DERIVATIVES', 'NOTE 5 —\n DERIVATIVES\n\nWe use derivative\n instruments to manage risks related to foreign currencies, equity\n prices, interest rates, and credit; to enhance investment returns;\n and to facilitate portfolio diversification. Our objectives for\n holding derivatives include reducing, eliminating, and efficiently\n managing the economic impact of these exposures as effectively as\n possible.\n\nOur derivative programs\n include strategies that both qualify and do not qualify for hedge\n accounting treatment. All notional amounts presented below are\n measured in U.S. dollar equivalents.\n\n \xa0\nForeign Currency\n\nCertain forecasted\n transactions, assets, and liabilities are exposed to foreign\n currency risk. We monitor our foreign currency exposures daily to\n maximize the economic effectiveness of our foreign currency hedge\n positions. Option and forward contracts are used to hedge a portion\n of forecasted international revenue for up to three years in the\n future and are designated as cash flow hedging instruments.\n Principal currencies hedged include the euro, Japanese yen, British\n pound, Canadian dollar, and Australian dollar. As of June\xa030,\n 2016 and June\xa030, 2015, the total notional amounts of these\n foreign exchange contracts sold were $8.4 billion and $9.8 billion,\n respectively.\n\nForeign currency risks\n related to certain non-U.S. dollar denominated securities are\n hedged using foreign exchange forward contracts that are designated\n as fair value hedging instruments. As of June\xa030, 2016 and\n June\xa030, 2015, the total notional amounts of these foreign\n exchange contracts sold were $5.3 billion for both\n periods.\n\nCertain options and\n forwards not designated as hedging instruments are also used to\n manage the variability in foreign exchange rates on certain balance\n sheet amounts and to manage other foreign currency\n exposures.\xa0As of June\xa030, 2016, the total notional\n amounts of these foreign exchange contracts purchased and sold were\n $12.0 billion and $11.7 billion, respectively. As of June\xa030,\n 2015, the total notional amounts of these foreign exchange\n contracts purchased and sold were $9.7 billion and $11.0 billion,\n respectively.\nEquity\n\nSecurities held in our\n equity and other investments portfolio are subject to market price\n risk.\xa0Market price risk is managed relative to broad-based\n global and domestic equity indices using certain convertible\n preferred investments, options, futures, and swap contracts not\n designated as hedging instruments. From time to time, to hedge our\n price risk, we may use and designate equity derivatives as hedging\n instruments, including puts, calls, swaps, and forwards.\xa0As of\n June\xa030, 2016, the total notional amounts of equity contracts\n purchased and sold for managing market price risk were $1.3 billion\n and $2.2 billion, respectively, of which $737 million and $986\n million, respectively, were designated as hedging instruments. As\n of June\xa030, 2015, the total notional amounts of equity\n contracts purchased and sold for managing market price risk were\n $2.2 billion and $2.6 billion, respectively, of which $1.1 billion\n and $1.4 billion, respectively, were designated as hedging\n instruments.\nInterest Rate\n\nSecurities held in our\n fixed-income portfolio are subject to different interest rate risks\n based on their maturities. We manage the average maturity of our\n fixed-income portfolio to achieve economic returns that correlate\n to certain broad-based fixed-income indices using exchange-traded\n option and futures contracts, and over-the-counter swap and option\n contracts, none of which are designated as hedging instruments. As\n of June\xa030, 2016, the total notional amounts of fixed-interest\n rate contracts purchased and sold were $328 million and $2.4\n billion, respectively. As of June\xa030, 2015, the total notional\n amounts of fixed-interest rate contracts purchased and sold were\n $1.0 billion and $3.2 billion, respectively.\n\nIn addition, we use\n “To Be Announced” forward purchase commitments of\n mortgage-backed assets to gain exposure to agency mortgage-backed\n securities.\xa0These meet the definition of a derivative\n instrument in cases where physical delivery of the assets is not\n taken at the earliest available delivery date. As of June\xa030,\n 2016 and 2015, the total notional derivative amounts of mortgage\n contracts purchased were $548 million and $812 million,\n respectively.\nCredit\n\nOur fixed-income\n portfolio is diversified and consists primarily of investment-grade\n securities. We use credit default swap contracts, not designated as\n hedging instruments, to manage credit exposures relative to\n broad-based indices and to facilitate portfolio diversification. We\n use credit default swaps as they are a low-cost method of managing\n exposure to individual credit risks or groups of credit risks. As\n of June\xa030, 2016, the total notional amounts of credit\n contracts purchased and sold were $440 million and $273 million,\n respectively. As of June\xa030, 2015, the total notional amounts\n of credit contracts purchased and sold were $618 million and $430\n million, respectively.\n\n \xa0\nCommodity\n\nWe use broad-based\n commodity exposures to enhance portfolio returns and to facilitate\n portfolio diversification. We use swaps, futures, and option\n contracts, not designated as hedging instruments, to generate and\n manage exposures to broad-based commodity indices. We use\n derivatives on commodities as they can be low-cost alternatives to\n the purchase and storage of a variety of commodities, including,\n but not limited to, precious metals, energy, and grain. As of\n June\xa030, 2016, the total notional amounts of commodity\n contracts purchased and sold were $631 million and $162 million,\n respectively. As of June\xa030, 2015, the total notional amounts\n of commodity contracts purchased and sold were $882 million and\n $316 million, respectively.\nCredit-Risk-Related Contingent\n Features\n\nCertain of our\n counterparty agreements for derivative instruments contain\n provisions that require our issued and outstanding long-term\n unsecured debt to maintain an investment grade credit rating and\n require us to maintain minimum liquidity of $1.0 billion. To the\n extent we fail to meet these requirements, we will be required to\n post collateral, similar to the standard convention related to\n over-the-counter derivatives. As of June\xa030, 2016, our\n long-term unsecured debt rating was AAA, and cash investments were\n in excess of $1.0 billion. As a result, no collateral was required\n to be posted.\n\n \xa0\nFair Values of Derivative\n Instruments\n\nThe following table\n presents the fair values of derivative instruments designated as\n hedging instruments (“designated hedge derivatives”)\n and not designated as hedging instruments (“non-designated\n hedge derivatives”). The fair values exclude the impact of\n netting derivative assets and liabilities when a legally\n enforceable master netting agreement exists and fair value\n adjustments related to our own credit risk and counterparty credit\n risk:\n\n \xa0\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\xa0\n\xa0\nJune\xa030,\n 2016\n\n\xa0\n\xa0\nJune\xa030,\n amount\n\n\xa0\n$\n(5\n)\xa0\n\xa0\n$\n246\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n$\n(7\n)\xa0\n\xa0\n$\n(482\n)\xa0\n\xa0\n$\n60\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n$\n648\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n$\n0\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n$\n(513\n)\xa0\n\n\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSee Contracts\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nDerivatives\n\n\xa0\xa0\n$\n(76\n)\xa0\n\xa0\n$\n(107\n)\xa0\n\xa0\n$\n(110\n)\xa0\n\n\n\nHedged items\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n76\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n107\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\xa0110\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nTotal amount of\n ineffectiveness\n\n\xa0\xa0\n$\n0\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n$\n0\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n$\n0\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nAmount of equity contracts excluded\n from effectiveness assessment\n\n\xa0\xa0\n$\n(10\n)\xa0\n\xa0\n$\n0\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n$\n(9\n)\xa0\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nCash Flow Hedge Gains\n (Losses)\n\nWe recognized the\n following gains (losses) on June\xa030,\n\xa0\xa0\n2016\n\xa0\n\xa0\n2015\n\xa0\n\xa0\n2014\n\xa0\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nEffective Portion\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nGains recognized in OCI (net of tax\n effects of $24, $35 and $2)\n\n\xa0\xa0\n$\n351\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n$\n\xa0\xa01,152\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n$\n63\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\nGains reclassified from AOCI into\n revenue\n\n\xa0\xa0\n$\n\xa0\xa0\xa0625\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n$\n608\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n$\n\xa0\xa0\xa0104\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nAmount Excluded from Effectiveness\n Assessment and Ineffective Portion\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nLosses recognized in other income\n (expense), net\n\n\xa0\xa0\n$\n(354\n)\xa0\n\xa0\n$\n(346\n)\xa0\n\xa0\n$\n(239\n)\xa0\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nWe estimate that $319\n million of net derivative gains included in AOCI as of\n June\xa030, 2016 will be reclassified into earnings within the\n following 12 months. No significant amounts of gains (losses) were\n reclassified from AOCI into earnings as a result of forecasted\n transactions that failed to occur during fiscal year\n 2016.\nNon-Designated Derivative Gains\n (Losses)\n\nGains (losses) from\n changes in fair values of derivatives that are not designated as\n hedges are primarily recognized in other income (expense), net.\n These amounts are shown in the table below, with the exception of\n gains (losses) on derivatives presented in income statement line\n items other than other income (expense), net, which were immaterial\n for the periods presented. Other than those derivatives entered\n into for investment purposes, such as commodity contracts, the\n gains (losses) below are generally economically offset by\n unrealized gains (losses) in the underlying available-for-sale\n securities and gains (losses) from foreign exchange rate changes on\n certain balance sheet amounts.\n\n \xa0\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n(In millions)\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nYear Ended June\xa030,\n\xa0\xa0\n2016\n\xa0\n\xa0\n2015\n\xa0\n\xa0\n2014\n\xa0\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nForeign exchange contracts\n\n\xa0\xa0\n$\n\xa0\xa0\xa0\xa0(55\n)\xa0\n\xa0\n$\n\xa0\xa0(483\n)\xa0\n\xa0\n$\n\xa0\xa0(78\n)\xa0\n\n\n\nEquity contracts\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n(21\n)\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n(19\n)\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n(64\n)\xa0\n\n\n\nInterest-rate contracts\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n10\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n23\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n24\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\nCredit contracts\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n(1\n)\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n(1\n)\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n13\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\nCommodity contracts\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n(87\n)\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n(223\n)\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n71\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nTotal\n\n\xa0\xa0\n$\n(154\n)\xa0\n\xa0\n$\n(703\n)\xa0\n\xa0\n$\n(34\n)', and other\n\n\xa0\xa0\n$\n5\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n$\n159\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n$\n54\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n$\n218\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n$\n(161\n)\xa0\n\xa0\n$\n57\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n \xa0\n\n\n(a)\n\nThese amounts represent the impact of netting derivative\n assets and derivative liabilities when a legally enforceable master\n netting agreement exists and fair value adjustments related to our\n own credit risk and counterparty credit risk.\n\n\n\n\nThe changes in our Level\n 3 financial instruments that are measured at fair value on a\n recurring basis were immaterial during the periods\n presented.\n\n \xa0\n\nThe following table\n reconciles the total “Net Fair Value” of assets above\n to our balance sheet presentation of these same assets in Note 4\n – Investments.\n\n ['X']
['- DefinitionThe entire disclosure for the fair value of financial instruments (as defined), including financial assets and financial liabilities (collectively, as defined), and the measurements of those instruments as well as disclosures related to the fair value of non-financial assets and liabilities. Such disclosures about the financial instruments, assets, and liabilities would include: (1) the fair value of the required items together with their carrying amounts (as appropriate); (2) for items for which it is not practicable to estimate fair value, disclosure would include: (a) information pertinent to estimating fair value (including, carrying amount, effective interest rate, and maturity, and (b) the reasons why it is not practicable to estimate fair value; (3) significant concentrations of credit risk including: (a) information about the activity, region, or economic characteristics identifying a concentration, (b) the maximum amount of loss the entity is exposed to based on the gross fair value of the related item, (c) policy for requiring collateral or other security and information as to accessing such collateral or security, and (d) the nature and brief description of such collateral or security; (4) quantitative information about market risks and how such risks are managed; (5) for items measured on both a recurring and nonrecurring basis information regarding the inputs used to develop the fair value measurement; and (6) for items presented in the financial statement for which fair value measurement is elected: (a) information necessary to understand the reasons for the election, (b) discussion of the effect of fair value changes on earnings, (c) a description of [similar groups] items for which the election is made and the relation thereof to the balance sheet, the aggregate carrying value of items included in the balance sheet that are not eligible for the election; (7) all other required (as defined) and desired information.\n+ ReferencesReference 1: http://www.xbrl.org/2003/role/presentationRef -Publisher FASB -Name Accounting Standards Codification -Topic 820 -SubTopic 10 -Section 50 -Paragraph 2 -URI http://asc.fasb.org/extlink&oid=66048111&loc=d3e19207-110258Reference 2: http://www.xbrl.org/2003/role/presentationRef -Publisher FASB -Name Accounting Standards Codification -Topic 825 -SubTopic 10 -Section 50 -Paragraph 30 -URI http://asc.fasb.org/extlink&oid=6957238&loc=d3e14172-108612Reference 3: http://www.xbrl.org/2003/role/presentationRef -Publisher FASB -Name Accounting Standards Codification -Topic 825 -SubTopic 10 -Section 50 -Paragraph 28 -URI http://asc.fasb.org/extlink&oid=6957238&loc=d3e14064-108612Reference 4: http://www.xbrl.org/2003/role/presentationRef -Publisher FASB -Name Accounting Standards Codification -Topic 825 -SubTopic 10 -Section 50 -Paragraph 21 -URI http://asc.fasb.org/extlink&oid=73719730&loc=d3e13537-108611Reference 5: http://www.xbrl.org/2003/role/presentationRef -Publisher FASB -Name Accounting Standards Codification -Topic 825 -SubTopic 10 -Section 50 -Paragraph 16 -URI http://asc.fasb.org/extlink&oid=73719730&loc=d3e13504-108611Reference 6: http://www.xbrl.org/2003/role/presentationRef -Publisher FASB -Name Accounting Standards Codification -Topic 825 -SubTopic 10 -Section 50 -Paragraph 10 -URI http://asc.fasb.org/extlink&oid=73719730&loc=d3e13433-108611\n+ Details\n\n Name:\nus-gaap_FairValueDisclosuresTextBlock\n\n\n Namespace Prefix:\nus-gaap_\n\n\n Data Type:\nnonnum:textBlockItemType\n\n\n Balance Type:\nna\n\n\n Period Type:\nduration', 'Name:', 'us-gaap_FairValueDisclosuresTextBlock', 'Namespace Prefix:', 'us-gaap_', 'Data Type:', 'nonnum:textBlockItemType', 'Balance Type:', 'na', 'Period Type:', 'duration']

['BUSINESS COMBINATIONS', '12 Months Ended']
['Jun. 30, 2016']
['BUSINESS COMBINATIONS', 'NOTE 9\n — BUSINESS COMBINATIONS\n\nMojang Synergies\n AB\nOn\n November\xa06, 2014, we acquired Mojang Synergies AB\n (“Mojang”), the Swedish video game developer of the\n Minecraft gaming franchise, for $2.5 billion in cash, net of cash\n acquired. The addition of Minecraft and its community enhances our\n gaming portfolio across Windows, Xbox, and other ecosystems besides\n our own. The significant classes of assets and liabilities to which\n we allocated the purchase price were goodwill of $1.8 billion and\n identifiable intangible assets of $928 million, primarily\n marketing-related (trade names). The goodwill recognized in\n connection with the acquisition is primarily attributable to\n anticipated synergies from future growth, and is not expected to be\n deductible for tax purposes. We assigned the goodwill to More\n Personal Computing under our current segment structure.\n Identifiable intangible assets were assigned a total\n weighted-average amortization period of 6.3 years. Mojang has been\n included in our consolidated results of operations since the\n acquisition date.\n\nNokia’s Devices\n and Services Business\nOn\n April\xa025, 2014, we acquired substantially all of Nokia\n Corporation’s (“Nokia”) Devices and Services\n business (“NDS”) for a total purchase price of $9.4\n billion, including cash acquired of $1.5 billion (the\n “Acquisition”). The purchase price consisted primarily\n of cash of $7.1 billion and Nokia’s repurchase of convertible\n notes of $2.1 billion, which was a non-cash transaction, and\n liabilities assumed of $0.2 billion. The Acquisition was expected\n to accelerate the growth of our Devices business through faster\n innovation, synergies, and unified branding and\n marketing.\nThe\n allocation of the purchase price to goodwill was completed as of\n March\xa031, 2015. The major classes of assets and liabilities to\n which we allocated the purchase price were as follows:\n\n \xa0\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n(In millions)\n\xa0\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nCash\n\n\xa0\xa0\n$\n1,506\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\nAccounts\n receivable\xa0(a)\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n754\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\nInventories\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n544\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\nOther current assets\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n936\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\nProperty and equipment\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n981\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\nIntangible assets\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n4,509\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\nGoodwill\xa0(b)\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n5,456\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\nOther\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n221\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\nCurrent liabilities\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n(4,575\n)\xa0\n\n\n\nLong-term liabilities\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n(890\n)\xa0\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nTotal purchase price\n\n\xa0\xa0\n$\n\xa0\xa0\xa09,442\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n \xa0\n\n\n(a)\n\nGross accounts receivable was $901 million, of which $147\n million was expected to be uncollectible.\n\n\n\n\n\n(b)\n\nGoodwill was assigned to More Personal Computing under our\n current segment structure. The goodwill was primarily attributed to\n increased synergies that were expected to be achieved from the\n integration of NDS.\n\n\n\n\nFollowing are the details\n of the purchase price allocated to the intangible assets\n acquired:\n\n \xa0\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n(In millions)\n\xa0\xa0\nAmount\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\n\nWeighted\n\nAverage\xa0Life\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nTechnology-based\n\n\xa0\xa0\n$\n\xa0\xa02,493\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n9\xa0years\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\nContract-based\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n1,500\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n9\xa0years\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\nCustomer-related\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n359\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n3\xa0years\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\nMarketing-related (trade\n names)\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n157\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n2\xa0years\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\n\n\nFair value of intangible assets\n acquired\n\n\xa0\xa0\n$\n4,509\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n8\xa0years\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\n\n\n \xa0\nDuring\n the fourth quarter of fiscal year 2016, we recorded $630 million of\n intangible and fixed asset impairment charges, and during the\n fourth quarter of fiscal year 2015, we recorded $7.5 billion of\n goodwill and asset impairment charges. The impairment charges for\n both periods related to our phone business. These costs are\n included in impairment, integration, and restructuring expenses on\n our consolidated income statement. See Note\xa010 –\n Goodwill and Note 11 – Intangible Assets for additional\n details.\nIn May\n 2016, we announced an agreement to sell our entry-level feature\n phone assets for $350 million. The transaction is expected to close\n in the second half of calendar year 2016, subject to regulatory\n approvals and other closing conditions.\nOur\n consolidated income statement for fiscal year 2014 included revenue\n and operating loss of $2.0 billion and $692 million, respectively,\n attributable to NDS since the Acquisition.\nFollowing\n are the supplemental consolidated results of Microsoft Corporation\n on an unaudited pro forma basis, as if the Acquisition had been\n consummated on July\xa01, 2012:\n\n \xa0\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n(In millions, except per share amounts)\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nYear Ended June\xa030,\n\xa0\xa0\n2014\n\xa0\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nRevenue\n\n\xa0\xa0\n$\n\xa0\xa096,248\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\nNet income\n\n\xa0\xa0\n$\n20,234\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\nDiluted earnings per share\n\n\xa0\xa0\n$\n2.41\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nThese pro\n forma results were based on estimates and assumptions, which we\n believe are reasonable. They are not the results that would have\n been realized had we been a combined company during the periods\n presented and are not necessarily indicative of our consolidated\n results of operations in future periods. The pro forma results\n include adjustments primarily related to purchase accounting\n adjustments and the elimination of related party transactions\n between Microsoft and NDS. Acquisition costs and other nonrecurring\n charges incurred are included in the earliest period\n presented.\nDuring\n the fourth quarter of fiscal year 2014, we incurred $21 million of\n acquisition costs associated with the purchase of NDS. Acquisition\n costs are primarily comprised of transaction fees and direct\n acquisition costs, including legal, finance, consulting, and other\n professional fees. These costs are included in impairment,\n integration, and restructuring expenses on our consolidated income\n statement for fiscal year 2014.\nCertain\n concurrent transactions were recognized separately from the\n Acquisition. Prior to the Acquisition, we had joint strategic\n initiatives with Nokia; this contractual relationship was\n terminated in conjunction with the Acquisition. No gain or loss was\n recorded upon termination of this agreement, as it was determined\n to be at market value. In addition, we agreed to license\n Nokia’s mapping services and will pay Nokia separately for\n the services provided under a four-year license as they are\n rendered.\n\nOther\nDuring\n fiscal year 2016, we completed 17 acquisitions for total cash\n consideration of $1.4 billion. Adjustments in purchase\n price allocations may require a recasting of the amounts allocated\n to goodwill retroactive to the periods in which the acquisitions\n occurred.\nAny\n change in the goodwill amounts resulting from foreign currency\n translations and purchase accounting adjustments are presented as\n “Other” in the above table. Also included in\n “Other” are business dispositions and transfers between\n business segments due to reorganizations, as applicable. For fiscal\n year 2015, a $5.1 billion goodwill impairment charge was included\n in “Other,” as discussed below. This goodwill\n impairment charge was included in impairment, integration, and\n restructuring expenses on our consolidated income statement, and\n reflected in Corporate and Other in our table of operating income\n (loss) by segment in Note 21 – Segment Information and\n Geographic Data.\nOur\n accumulated goodwill impairment as of both June\xa030, 2016 and\n 2015 was $11.3 billion.\nAs\n discussed in Note 21 – Segment Information and Geographic\n Data, during the first quarter of fiscal year 2016 our chief\n operating decision maker requested changes in the information that\n he regularly reviews for purposes of allocating resources and\n assessing performance. This resulted in a change in our operating\n segments and reporting units. We allocated goodwill to our new\n reporting units using a relative fair value approach. In addition,\n we completed an assessment of any potential goodwill impairment for\n all reporting units immediately prior to the reallocation and\n determined that no impairment existed.\n\nGoodwill\n Impairment\nWe test\n goodwill for impairment annually on May\xa01 at the reporting\n unit level, primarily using a discounted cash flow methodology with\n a peer-based, risk-adjusted weighted average cost of capital. We\n believe use of a discounted cash flow approach is the most reliable\n indicator of the fair values of the businesses.\nNo\n instances of impairment were identified in our May\xa01, 2016\n test.\nUpon\n completion of the annual testing as of May\xa01, 2015, our\n previous Phone Hardware reporting unit goodwill was determined to\n be impaired. Phone Hardware goodwill is included in the Devices\n reporting unit within More Personal Computing under our current\n segment structure. In the second half of fiscal year 2015, Phone\n Hardware did not meet its sales volume and revenue goals, and the\n mix of units sold had lower margins than planned. These results,\n along with changes in the competitive marketplace and an evaluation\n of business priorities, led to a shift in strategic direction and\n reduced future revenue and profitability expectations for the\n business. As a result of these changes in strategy and\n expectations, we forecasted reductions in unit volume growth rates\n and lower future cash flows used to estimate the fair value of the\n Phone Hardware reporting unit, which resulted in the determination\n that an impairment adjustment was required.\nBecause\n our annual test indicated that Phone Hardware’s carrying\n value exceeded its estimated fair value, a second phase of the\n goodwill impairment test (“Step 2”) was performed\n specific to Phone Hardware. Under Step 2, the fair value of all\n Phone Hardware assets and liabilities were estimated, including\n tangible assets, existing technology, patent agreements, and\n contractual arrangements, for the purpose of deriving an estimate\n of the implied fair value of goodwill. The implied fair value of\n the goodwill was then compared to the recorded goodwill to\n determine the amount of the impairment. Assumptions used in\n measuring the value of these assets and liabilities included the\n discount rates and royalty rates used in valuing the intangible\n assets, and consideration of the market environment in valuing the\n tangible assets.\nNo other\n instances of impairment were identified in our May\xa01, 2015\n test.', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '(In millions)', '', 'June\xa030,\n\n2014', '', '', 'Acquisitions', '', '', 'Other', '', '', 'June\xa030,\n\n2015', '', '', 'Acquisitions', '', '', 'Other', '', '', 'June\xa030,\n 2016', '', '', '', 'Productivity and Business\n Processes', '', '$', '6,116', '', '', '$', '376', '', '', '$', '(183', ')', '', '$', '6,309', '', '', '$', '443', '', '', '$', '(74', ')', '', '$', '6,678', '', 'Intelligent Cloud', '', '', '4,631', '', '', '', '291', '', '', '', '(5', ')', '', '', '4,917', '', '', '', '549', '', '', '', '1', '', '', '', '5,467', '', 'More Personal Computing', '', '', '9,380', '', '', '', '1,788', '', '', '', '(5,455', ')', '', '', '5,713', '', '', '', '100', '', '', '', '(86', ')', '', '', '5,727', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', 'Total goodwill', '', '$', '20,127', '', '', '$', '2,455', '', '', '$', '(5,643', ')', '', '$', '16,939', '', '', '$', '1,092', '', '', '$', '(159', ')', '', '$', '17,872', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '']

['INTANGIBLE ASSETS', 'NOTE 11\n — INTANGIBLE ASSETS\n\nThe components of\n intangible assets, all of which are finite-lived, were as\n follows:\n\n \xa0\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n(In millions)\n\xa0\xa0\nGross\n Carrying\n Amount\n\xa0\n\xa0\nAccumulated\n Amortization\n\xa0\n\xa0\nNet\xa0Carrying\n \xa0\n\n\n(a)\n\nTechnology-based intangible assets included $115 million and\n $116 million as of June\xa030, 2016 and 2015, respectively, of\n net carrying amount of software to be sold, leased, or otherwise\n marketed.\n\n\n\nIn the\n third quarter of fiscal year 2016, we corrected our intangible\n assets in the table above for a $585 million misstatement between\n gross carrying amount and accumulated amortization as of\n June\xa030, 2015. We do not consider this correction to be\n material, and there was no impact to our consolidated financial\n statements.\nDuring\n fiscal year 2016, we recorded impairment charges of $480 million\n related to intangible assets in the Devices reporting unit within\n our More Personal Computing segment. In the fourth quarter of\n fiscal year 2016, we tested these intangible assets for\n recoverability due to changes in facts and circumstances associated\n with the shift in strategic direction and reduced profitability\n expectations for our phone business. Based on the results of our\n testing, we determined that the carrying value of the intangible\n assets was not recoverable, and an impairment charge was recorded\n to the extent that estimated fair value exceeded carrying value. We\n primarily used the income approach to determine the fair value of\n the intangible assets and determine the amount of\n impairment.\nDuring\n fiscal year 2015, we recorded impairment charges of $2.2 billion\n related to intangible assets in our previous Phone Hardware\n reporting unit. Phone Hardware intangible assets are included in\n the Devices reporting unit under our current segment structure. In\n the fourth quarter of fiscal year 2015, we tested these intangible\n assets for recoverability due to changes in facts and circumstances\n associated with the shift in strategic direction and reduced\n profitability expectations for Phone Hardware. Based on the results\n of our testing, we determined that the carrying value of the\n intangible assets was not recoverable, and an impairment charge was\n recorded to the extent that estimated fair value exceeded carrying\n value. We primarily used a relief from royalty income approach to\n determine the fair value of the intangible assets and determine the\n amount of impairment.\nThese\n intangible assets impairment charges were included in impairment,\n integration, and restructuring expenses on our consolidated income\n statement, and reflected in Corporate and Other in our table of\n operating income (loss) by segment in Note 21 – Segment\n Information and Geographic Data.\n\nWe estimate that we have\n no significant residual value related to our intangible\n assets.\n\n \xa0\n\nThe components of\n intangible assets acquired during the periods presented were as\n follows:\n\n \xa0\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n(In millions)\n\xa0\xa0\nAmount\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\n\nWeighted\n\nAverage\xa0Life\n\n\xa0\n\xa0\nAmount\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\n\nWeighted\n\nAverage\xa0Life\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nYear Ended June\xa030,\n\xa0\xa0\n2016\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n2015\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nTechnology-based\n\n\xa0\xa0\n$\n361\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n4\xa0years\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n$\n874\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n5\xa0years\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\nMarketing-related\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n2\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n1\xa0year\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n543\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n8\xa0years\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\nCustomer-related\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n30\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n3\xa0years\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n37\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n4\xa0years\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\n\n\nTotal\n\n\xa0\xa0\n$\n\xa0\xa0393\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n4\xa0years\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n$\n\xa0\xa01,454\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n6\xa0years\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\n\nIntangible assets amortization expense was $978 million, $1.3\n billion, and $845 million for fiscal years 2016, 2015, and 2014,\n respectively. ['Jun. 30, 2016']
['DEBT', 'NOTE 12 —\n DEBT\nShort-term Debt\n\nAs of June\xa030, 2016,\n we had $12.9 billion of commercial paper issued and outstanding,\n with a weighted-average interest rate of 0.43% and maturities\n ranging from 1 day to 99 days. As of June\xa030, 2015, we had\n $5.0 billion of commercial paper issued and outstanding, with a\n weighted-average interest rate of 0.11% and maturities ranging from\n 8 days to 63 days. The estimated fair value of this commercial\n paper approximates its carrying value.\n\nWe have two $5.0 billion\n credit facilities that expire on November\xa01, 2016 and\n November\xa014, 2018, respectively. These credit facilities serve\n as a back-up for our commercial paper program. As of June\xa030,\n 2016, we were in compliance with the only financial covenant in\n both credit agreements, which requires us to maintain a coverage\n ratio of at least three times earnings before interest, taxes,\n depreciation, and amortization to interest expense, as defined in\n the credit agreements. No amounts were drawn against these credit\n facilities during any of the periods presented.\nLong-term Debt\n\nAs of June\xa030, 2016,\n the total carrying value and estimated fair value of our long-term\n debt were $40.8 billion and $44.0 billion, respectively. This is\n compared to a carrying value and estimated fair value of our\n long-term debt, including the current portion, of $30.3 billion and\n $30.5 billion, respectively, as of June\xa030, 2015. These\n estimated fair values are based on Level 2 inputs.\n\n \xa0\n\nThe components of our\n long-term debt, including the current portion, and the associated\n interest rates were as follows as of Interest on these notes is\n paid semi-annually, except for the euro-denominated debt securities\n on which interest is paid annually. Cash paid for interest on our\n debt for fiscal years 2016, 2015, and 2014 was $1.1 billion, $620\n million, and $509 million, respectively. ['- DefinitionThe entire disclosure for information about short-term and long-term debt arrangements, which includes amounts of borrowings under each line of credit, note payable, commercial paper issue, bonds indenture, debenture issue, own-share lending arrangements and any other contractual agreement to repay funds, and about the underlying arrangements, rationale for a classification as long-term, including repayment terms, interest rates, collateral provided, restrictions on use of assets and activities, whether or not in compliance with debt covenants, and other matters important to users of the financial statements, such as the effects of refinancing and noncompliance with debt covenants.\n+ ReferencesReference 1: http://www.xbrl.org/2003/role/presentationRef -Publisher FASB -Name Accounting Standards Codification -Topic 505 -SubTopic 10 -Section 50 -Paragraph 3 -URI http://asc.fasb.org/extlink&oid=6928386&loc=d3e21475-112644Reference 2: http://www.xbrl.org/2003/role/presentationRef -Publisher FASB -Name Accounting Standards Codification -Topic 210 -SubTopic 10 -Section S99 -Paragraph 1 -Subparagraph (SX 210.5-02.19,20,22) -URI http://asc.fasb.org/extlink&oid=6877327&loc=d3e13212-122682\n+ Details\n\n Name:\nus-gaap_DebtDisclosureTextBlock\n\n\n Namespace Prefix:\nus-gaap_\n\n\n Data Type:\nnonnum:textBlockItemType\n\n\n Balance Type:\nna\n\n\n Period Type:\nduration', 'Name:', 'us-gaap_DebtDisclosureTextBlock', 'Namespace Prefix:', 'us-gaap_', 'Data Type:', 'nonnum:textBlockItemType', 'Balance Type:', 'na', 'Period Type:', 'duration']

before income taxes\n\n\xa0\xa0\n$\n\xa0\xa019,751\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n$\n\xa0\xa018,507\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n$\n\xa0\xa027,820\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nIn fiscal\n year 2016, income before income taxes included the net impact of\n U.S. and foreign revenue deferrals related to the sales of Windows\n 10 of $6.0 billion and $588 million, respectively. In fiscal year\n 2015, income before income taxes included the net impact of U.S.\n and foreign impairment, integration, and restructuring expenses\n relating to our phone business of $1.1 billion and $8.9 billion,\n respectively.\nThe items\n accounting for the difference between income taxes computed at the\n U.S. federal statutory rate and our effective rate were as\n follows:\n\n \xa0\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\n\nYear Ended June\xa030,\n\xa0\xa0\n2016\n\xa0\n\xa0\n2015\n\xa0\n\xa0\n2014\n\xa0\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nFederal statutory of:\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\n\n\nForeign earnings taxed at lower\n allowance\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n1.3%\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n19.1%\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n0.9%\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\nDomestic production activities\n deduction\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n(0.6)%\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n(2.4)%\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n(1.0)%\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\nExcess tax benefits relating to\n stock-based compensation\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n(2.0)%\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n0%\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n0%\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\nOther reconciling items,\n net\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n0.7%\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n3.3%\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n2.9%\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nEffective rate\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n15.0%\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n34.1%\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n20.7%\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n \xa0\nThe\n reduction from the federal statutory rate is primarily due to\n earnings taxed at lower rates in foreign jurisdictions resulting\n from producing and distributing our products and services through\n our foreign regional operations centers in Ireland, Singapore, and\n Puerto Rico. Our foreign regional operating centers, which are\n taxed at rates lower than the U.S. rate, generated 69%, 73%, and\n 81% of our foreign income before tax in fiscal years 2016, 2015,\n and 2014, respectively. In general, other reconciling items consist\n of interest, U.S. state income taxes, and credits. In fiscal years\n 2016, 2015, and 2014, there were no individually significant other\n reconciling items.\nThe\n decrease in our effective tax rate for fiscal year 2016 compared to\n fiscal year 2015 was primarily due to changes in the mix of our\n income before income taxes between the U.S. and foreign countries,\n including the net impact of revenue deferrals related to sales of\n Windows 10, tax benefits from the adoption of the new accounting\n guidance relating to stock-based compensation, and distributions\n from foreign affiliates. The fiscal year 2015 effective tax rate\n included the tax impact of losses in foreign jurisdictions for\n which we may not realize a tax benefit, primarily as a result of\n impairment and restructuring charges.\nThe\n components of the deferred income tax assets and liabilities were\n as follows:\n\n \xa0\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n(In liabilities\xa0(a)\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n(1,476\n)\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n(1,295\n)\xa0\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nNet deferred income tax assets\n (liabilities)\xa0(a)\n\n\xa0\xa0\n$\n(1,257\n)\xa0\n\xa0\n$\n(1,067\n)\xa0\n\n\n\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n \xa0\n\n\n(a)\n\nBalances as of June\xa030, 2015 reflect the impact of the\n adoption of the new accounting standard in fiscal year 2016 related\n to balance sheet classification of deferred taxes. See Note 1\n – Accounting Policies for additional details.\n\n\n\nAs of\n June\xa030, 2016, we had net operating loss carryforwards of $8.0\n billion, including $6.3 billion of foreign net operating loss\n carryforwards. The valuation allowance disclosed in the table above\n relates to the foreign net operating loss carryforwards and other\n net deferred tax assets that may not be realized.\n\n \xa0\nDeferred\n income tax balances reflect the effects of temporary differences\n between the carrying amounts of assets and liabilities and their\n tax bases and are stated at enacted tax rates expected to be in\n effect when the taxes are actually paid or recovered.\nAs of\n June\xa030, 2016, we have not provided deferred U.S. income taxes\n or foreign withholding taxes on temporary differences of\n approximately $124.0 billion resulting from earnings for certain\n non-U.S. subsidiaries which are permanently reinvested outside the\n U.S. The unrecognized deferred tax liability associated with these\n temporary differences was approximately $39.3 billion as of\n June\xa030, 2016.\nIncome\n taxes paid were $3.9 billion, $4.4 billion, and $5.5 billion in\n fiscal years 2016, 2015, and 2014, respectively.\nTax\n contingencies and other income tax liabilities were $11.8 billion\n and $12.1 billion as of June\xa030, 2016 and 2015, respectively,\n and are included in other long-term liabilities. This decrease\n relates primarily to tax credits available for carryover and a\n partial settlement of the IRS audit for tax years 2007 to 2009,\n offset by increases relating to intercompany transfer\n pricing.\n\nUncertain Tax\n Positions\nUnrecognized tax benefits as of June\xa030, 2016, 2015, and\n 2014, were $10.2 billion, $9.6 billion, and $8.7 billion,\n respectively. If recognized, these tax benefits would affect our\n effective tax rates for fiscal years 2016, 2015, and 2014, by $8.8\n billion, $7.9 billion, and $7.0 billion, respectively.\nAs of\n June\xa030, 2016, 2015, and 2014, we had accrued interest expense\n related to uncertain tax positions of $1.9 billion, $1.7 billion,\n and $1.5 billion, respectively, net of federal income tax benefits.\n Interest expense on unrecognized tax benefits was $163 million,\n $237 million, and $235 million in fiscal years 2016, 2015, and\n 2014, respectively, and was included in provision for income\n taxes.\nThe\n aggregate changes in the balance of unrecognized tax benefits were\n as follows:\n\n \xa0\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n(In millions)\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nYear Ended June\xa030,\n\xa0\xa0\n2016\n\xa0\n\xa0\n2015\n\xa0\n\xa0\n2014\n\xa0\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nBalance, beginning of year\n\n\xa0\xa0\n$\n9,599\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n$\n8,714\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n$\n8,648\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\nDecreases related to\n settlements\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n(201\n)\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n(50\n)\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n(583\n)\xa0\n\n\n\nIncreases for tax positions related\n to the current year\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n1,086\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n1,091\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n566\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\nIncreases for tax positions related\n to prior years\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n115\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n94\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n217\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\nDecreases for tax positions related\n to prior years\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n(317\n)\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n(144\n)\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n(95\n)\xa0\n\n\n\nDecreases due to lapsed statutes of\n limitations\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n(118\n)\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n(106\n)\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n(39\n)\xa0\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nBalance, end of year\n\n\xa0\xa0\n$\n\xa0\xa010,164\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n$\n\xa0\xa09,599\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n$\n\xa0\xa08,714\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nWhile we\n settled a portion of our IRS audit for tax years 2004 to 2006\n during the third quarter of fiscal year 2011, and settled a portion\n of the IRS audit for tax years 2007 to 2009 during the first\n quarter of fiscal year 2016, we remain under audit for those years.\n In February 2012, the IRS withdrew its 2011 Revenue Agents Report\n for tax years 2004 to 2006 and reopened the audit phase of the\n examination. As of June\xa030, 2016, the primary unresolved issue\n relates to transfer pricing, which could have a significant impact\n on our consolidated financial statements if not resolved favorably.\n We believe our allowances for income tax contingencies are\n adequate. We have not received a proposed assessment for the\n unresolved issues and do not expect a final resolution of these\n issues in the next 12 months.\xa0Based on the information\n currently available, we do not anticipate a significant increase or\n decrease to our tax contingencies for these issues within the next\n 12 months. We also continue to be subject to examination by the IRS\n for tax years 2010 to 2016.\nWe are\n subject to income tax in many jurisdictions outside the U.S. Our\n operations in certain jurisdictions remain subject to examination\n for tax years 1996 to 2016, some of which are currently under audit\n by local tax authorities. The resolutions of these audits are not\n expected to be material to our consolidated financial\n statements.', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '', '(In millions)', '', '', '', '', '', ["- DefinitionThe entire disclosure for income taxes. Disclosures may include net deferred tax liability or asset recognized in an enterprise's statement of financial position, net change during the year in the total valuation allowance, approximate tax effect of each type of temporary difference and carryforward that gives rise to a significant portion of deferred tax liabilities and deferred tax assets, utilization of a tax carryback, and tax uncertainties information.\n+ ReferencesReference 1: http://www.xbrl.org/2003/role/presentationRef -Publisher FASB -Name Accounting Standards Codification -Topic 235 -SubTopic 10 -Section S99 -Paragraph 1 -Subparagraph (SX 210.4-08.(h)) -URI http://asc.fasb.org/extlink&oid=26873400&loc=d3e23780-122690Reference 2: http://www.xbrl.org/2003/role/presentationRef -Publisher FASB -Name Accounting Standards Codification -Topic 740 -SubTopic 10 -Section 50 -Paragraph 3 -URI http://asc.fasb.org/extlink&oid=65882285&loc=d3e32559-109319Reference 3: http://www.xbrl.org/2003/role/presentationRef -Publisher FASB -Name Accounting Standards Codification -Topic 740 -SubTopic 10 -Section 50 -Paragraph 15 -URI http://asc.fasb.org/extlink&oid=65882285&loc=d3e32718-109319Reference 4: http://www.xbrl.org/2003/role/presentationRef -Publisher FASB -Name Accounting Standards Codification -Topic 740 -SubTopic 10 -Section 50 -Paragraph 9 -URI http://asc.fasb.org/extlink&oid=65882285&loc=d3e32639-109319Reference 5: http://www.xbrl.org/2003/role/presentationRef -Publisher FASB -Name Accounting Standards Codification -Topic 740 -SubTopic 10 -Section 50 -Paragraph 2 -URI http://asc.fasb.org/extlink&oid=65882285&loc=d3e32537-109319\n+ Details\n\n Name:\nus-gaap_IncomeTaxDisclosureTextBlock\n\n\n Namespace Prefix:\nus-gaap_\n\n\n Data Type:\nnonnum:textBlockItemType\n\n\n Balance Type:\nna\n\n\n Period Type:\nduration", 'Name:', 'us-gaap_IncomeTaxDisclosureTextBlock', 'Namespace Prefix:', 'us-gaap_', 'Data Type:', 'nonnum:textBlockItemType', 'Balance Type:', 'na', 'Period Type:', 'duration']

Table:
['RESTRUCTURING CHARGES', '12 Months Ended']
['Jun. 30, 2016']
['RESTRUCTURING CHARGES', 'NOTE 14\n —\xa0RESTRUCTURING CHARGES\n\nPhone Hardware\n Integration\nIn July\n 2014, we announced a restructuring plan to simplify our\n organization and align NDS with our company’s overall\n strategy (the “Phone Hardware Integration Plan”).\n Pursuant to the Phone Hardware Integration Plan, we eliminated\n approximately 19,000 positions in fiscal year 2015, including\n approximately 13,000 professional and factory positions related to\n the NDS business. The actions associated with the Phone Hardware\n Integration Plan were completed as of June\xa030,\n 2015.\nIn\n connection with the Phone Hardware Integration Plan, we incurred\n total restructuring charges of $1.3 billion, including severance\n expenses and other reorganization costs, primarily associated with\n our facilities consolidation and write-downs of certain assets. All\n restructuring charges incurred under the Phone Hardware Integration\n Plan were recognized in fiscal year 2015.\n\nPhone Hardware\n Restructuring\nIn June\n 2015, management approved a plan to restructure our phone business\n to better focus and align resources (the “Phone Hardware\n Restructuring Plan”), under which we eliminated approximately\n 7,400 positions in fiscal year 2016.\nIn fiscal\n year 2015, we incurred restructuring charges of $780 million under\n the Phone Hardware Restructuring Plan, including severance expenses\n and other reorganization costs. In fiscal year 2016, we reversed\n $21 million of previously estimated restructuring charges related\n to contract termination costs. The actions associated with the\n Phone Hardware Restructuring Plan were substantially complete as of\n June\xa030, 2016, and are expected to be completed by the end of\n calendar year 2016.\n\n2016\n Restructuring\nWe\n periodically evaluate how to best deploy the company’s\n resources. In the fourth quarter of 2016, management approved\n restructuring plans that would result in job eliminations,\n primarily across our smartphone hardware business and global sales.\n In addition to the elimination of 1,850 positions that were\n announced in May 2016, approximately 2,850 roles globally will be\n reduced during the year as an extension of the earlier plan, and\n these actions are expected to be completed by the end of fiscal\n year 2017.\nIn\n connection with the restructuring plans, we incurred restructuring\n charges of $501 million in fiscal year 2016, including severance\n expenses and other reorganization costs. We do not expect to incur\n additional charges for these restructuring plans in subsequent\n years.\nRestructuring charges associated with each of these plans were\n included in impairment, integration, and restructuring expenses on\n our consolidated income statement, and reflected in Corporate and\n Other in our table of operating income (loss) by segment in Note\n 21– Segment Information and Geographic Data.\nChanges\n in the restructuring liability were as follows:\n\n \xa0\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n(In ['- DefinitionThe entire disclosure for deferred revenues at the end of the reporting period, and description and amounts of significant changes that occurred during the reporting period. Deferred revenue is a liability as of the balance sheet date related to a revenue producing activity for which revenue has not yet been recognized. Generally, an entity records deferred revenue when it receives consideration from a customer before achieving certain criteria that must be met for revenue to be recognized in conformity with GAAP.\n+ ['COMMITMENTS', 'NOTE 16\n — COMMITMENTS\n\nConstruction and\n Operating Lease Commitments\nWe have\n committed $2.0 billion for constructing new buildings, building\n improvements, and leasehold improvements as of June\xa030,\n 2016.\nWe have\n operating leases for most U.S. and international sales and support\n offices, research and development facilities, manufacturing\n facilities, retail stores, and certain equipment. Rental expense\n for facilities operating leases was $1.0 billion, $989 million, and\n $874 million, in fiscal years 2016, 2015, and 2014, respectively.\n Future minimum rental commitments under non-cancellable facilities\n operating leases in place as of June\xa030, 2016 are as\n follows:\n\n \xa0\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n(In millions)\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nYear Ending\n June\xa030,\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n2017\n\n\xa0\xa0\n$\n961\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\n2018\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n996\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\n2019\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n922\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\n2020\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n833\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\n2021\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n634\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\nThereafter\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n2,118\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nTotal\n\n\xa0\xa0\n$\n\xa0\xa06,464\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nOther\n Commitments\nOn\n June\xa011, 2016, we entered into a definitive agreement to\n acquire LinkedIn Corporation (“LinkedIn”) for $196 per\n share in an all-cash transaction valued at $26.2 billion, inclusive\n of LinkedIn’s net cash (the “Merger Agreement”).\n We will finance the transaction primarily through the issuance of\n new indebtedness. ['CONTINGENCIES', '12 Months Ended']
['Jun. 30, 2016']
['CONTINGENCIES', 'NOTE 17\n — CONTINGENCIES\n\nPatent and\n Intellectual Property Claims\n\nIPCom patent\n litigation\nIPCom\n GmbH\xa0& Co. (“IPCom”) is a German company that\n holds a large portfolio of mobile technology-related patents\n spanning about 170 patent families and addressing a broad range of\n cellular technologies. IPCom has asserted 19 of these patents in\n litigation against Nokia and many of the leading cell phone\n companies and operators. In November 2014, Microsoft and IPCom\n entered into a standstill agreement staying all of the pending\n litigation against Microsoft to permit the parties to pursue\n settlement discussions.\n\nInterDigital patent\n litigation\nInterDigital Technology Corporation and InterDigital\n Communications Corporation (collectively, “IDT”) filed\n four patent infringement cases against Nokia in the International\n Trade Commission (“ITC”) and in U.S. District Court for\n the District of Delaware between 2007 and 2013. We have been added\n to these cases as a defendant. IDT has cases pending against other\n defendants based on the same patents because most of the patents at\n issue allegedly relate to 3G and 4G wireless communications\n standards essential functionality. The cases involving us include\n three ITC investigations where IDT sought an order excluding\n importation of 3G and 4G phones into the U.S. and one active case\n in U.S. District Court in Delaware seeking an injunction and\n damages. Each of the ITC matters has been resolved in our favor. In\n September 2015, in an\xa0inter\n partes\xa0review\n the United States Patent Trial and Appeal Board issued a final\n written decision that deemed unpatentable all asserted claims of\n the patent remaining at issue in the Delaware case. IDT has\n appealed this decision to the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Federal\n Circuit. The Delaware case has been stayed pending final completion\n of the\xa0inter\n partes\xa0review\n (including appeals and any subsequent proceedings in the Patent\n Office). We filed an antitrust complaint against IDT in the\n District of Delaware in August 2015 asserting violations of\n Section\xa02 of the Sherman Act, alleging the unlawful\n exploitation of standard essential patents. IDT filed a motion to\n dismiss, which the District Court denied.\n\nEuropean copyright\n levies\nWe\n assumed from Nokia all potential liability due to Nokia’s\n alleged failure to pay “private copying levies” in\n various European countries based upon sale of memory cards and\n mobile phones that incorporate blank memory.\xa0The levies are\n based upon a 2001 European Union (“EU”) Directive\n establishing a right for end users to make copies of copyrighted\n works for personal or private use, but also allowing the collection\n of levies based upon sales of blank media or recording devices to\n compensate copyright holders for private copying.\xa0Various\n collecting societies in EU countries initiated litigation against\n Nokia, stating that Nokia must pay levies not only based upon sales\n of blank memory cards, but also phones that include blank memory\n for data storage on the phones, regardless of actual usage of that\n memory.\xa0The most significant cases against Nokia are pending\n in Germany and Austria, due to both the high volume of sales and\n high levy amounts sought in these countries. In December 2015, the\n industry group BITKOM, of which we are a member, reached a\n settlement with the German collecting society for all claims from\n 2008 forward, leaving litigation only for the period 2004-2007\n pending in Germany. In addition, the industry is engaged in\n settlement negotiations with the Austrian collecting society. We\n have also settled copyright levies litigation in Spain and\n France.\n\nOther patent and\n intellectual property claims\nIn\n addition to these cases, there were 54 other patent infringement\n cases pending against Microsoft as of June\xa030,\n 2016.\n\nAntitrust, Unfair\n Competition, and Overcharge Class Actions\nAntitrust\n and unfair competition class action lawsuits were filed against us\n in British Columbia, Ontario, and Quebec, Canada. All three have\n been certified on behalf of Canadian indirect purchasers who\n acquired licenses for Microsoft operating system software and/or\n productivity application software between 1998 and 2010.\n\n \xa0\nThe trial\n of the British Columbia action commenced in May 2016. The\n plaintiffs are expected to file their case in chief in August 2016,\n setting out claims made, authorities, and evidence in\n support.\xa0A six-month oral hearing is scheduled to commence in\n September 2017, consisting of cross examination on witness\n affidavits. The Ontario and Quebec cases are inactive.\n\nOther Antitrust\n Litigation and Claims\n\nChina State\n Administration for Industry and Commerce\n investigation\nIn 2014,\n Microsoft was informed that China’s State Administration for\n Industry and Commerce (“SAIC”) had begun a formal\n investigation relating to China’s Anti-Monopoly Law, and the\n SAIC conducted onsite inspections of Microsoft offices in Beijing,\n Shanghai, Guangzhou, and Chengdu.\xa0SAIC has stated the\n investigation relates to compatibility, bundle sales, file\n verification issues related to Windows and Office software, and\n potentially other issues.\n\nProduct-Related\n Litigation\n\nU.S. cell phone\n litigation\nNokia,\n along with other handset manufacturers and network operators, is a\n defendant in 19 lawsuits filed in the Superior Court for the\n District of Columbia by individual plaintiffs who allege that radio\n emissions from cellular handsets caused their brain tumors and\n other adverse health effects. We assumed responsibility for these\n claims as part of the NDS acquisition and have been substituted for\n the Nokia defendants. Nine of these cases were filed in 2002 and\n are consolidated for certain pre-trial proceedings; the remaining\n 10 cases are stayed. In a separate 2009 decision, the Court of\n Appeals for the District of Columbia held that adverse health\n effect claims arising from the use of cellular handsets that\n operate within the U.S. Federal Communications Commission radio\n frequency emission guidelines (“FCC Guidelines”) are\n pre-empted by federal law. The plaintiffs allege that their\n handsets either operated outside the FCC Guidelines or were\n manufactured before the FCC Guidelines went into effect. The\n lawsuits also allege an industry-wide conspiracy to manipulate the\n science and testing around emission guidelines.\nIn 2013,\n defendants in the consolidated cases moved to exclude\n plaintiffs’ expert evidence of general causation on the basis\n of flawed scientific methodologies. In 2014, the court granted in\n part defendants’ motion to exclude plaintiffs’ general\n causation experts. The plaintiffs filed an interlocutory appeal\n challenging the standard for evaluating expert scientific evidence,\n which the District of Columbia Court of Appeals agreed to\n hear\xa0en\n banc. Trial court proceedings are stayed pending resolution of\n the appeal.\n\nCanadian cell phone\n class action\nNokia,\n along with other handset manufacturers and network operators, is a\n defendant in a 2013 class action lawsuit filed in the Supreme Court\n of British Columbia by a purported class of Canadians who have used\n cellular phones for at least 1,600 hours, including a subclass of\n users with brain tumors. Microsoft was served with the complaint in\n June 2014 and has been substituted for the Nokia defendants. The\n litigation is not yet active as several defendants remain to be\n served.\n\nOther\nWe also\n are subject to a variety of other claims and suits that arise from\n time to time in the ordinary course of our business. Although\n management currently believes that resolving claims against us,\n individually or in aggregate, will not have a material adverse\n impact on our consolidated financial statements, these matters are\n subject to inherent uncertainties and management’s view of\n these matters may change in the future.\nAs of\n June\xa030, 2016, we accrued aggregate legal liabilities of $521\n million in other current liabilities. While we intend to defend\n these matters vigorously, adverse outcomes that we estimate could\n reach approximately $1.6 billion in aggregate beyond recorded\n amounts are reasonably possible. Were unfavorable final outcomes to\n occur, there exists the possibility of a material adverse impact on\n our consolidated financial statements for the period in which the\n effects become reasonably estimable.\n\n \xa0\n\nIndemnifications\nWe\n provide indemnifications of varying scope and size to certain\n customers against claims of intellectual property infringement made\n by third parties arising from the use of our products and certain\n other matters. Additionally, we have agreed to cover damages\n resulting from breaches of certain security and privacy commitments\n in our cloud business. We evaluate estimated losses for these\n indemnifications, and we consider such factors as the degree of\n probability of an unfavorable outcome and the ability to make a\n reasonable estimate of the amount of loss. To date, we have not\n encountered significant costs as a result of these obligations and\n have not accrued any liabilities related to these indemnifications\n on our consolidated financial statements.']

['EMPLOYEE STOCK AND SAVINGS PLANS', 'NOTE 20 —\n EMPLOYEE STOCK AND SAVINGS PLANS\n\nWe grant stock-based\n compensation to employees and directors. As of June\xa030, 2016\n an aggregate of 214\xa0million shares were authorized for future\n grant under our stock plans. Awards that expire or are canceled\n without delivery of shares generally become available for issuance\n under the plans. We issue new shares of Microsoft common stock to\n satisfy exercises and vesting of awards granted under all of our\n stock plans. We also have an ESPP for all eligible\n employees.\n\nStock-based compensation\n expense and related income tax benefits were as follows:\n\n \xa0\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n(In millions)\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nYear Ended June\xa030,\n\xa0\xa0\n2016\n\xa0\n\xa0\n2015\n\xa0\n\xa0\n2014\n\xa0\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nStock-based compensation\n expense\n\n\xa0\xa0\n$\n\xa0\xa02,668\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n$\n\xa0\xa02,574\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n$\n\xa0\xa02,446\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\nIncome tax benefits related to\n stock-based compensation\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n882\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n868\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n830\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nStock Plans\n\nStock awards entitle the\n holder to receive shares of Microsoft common stock as the award\n vests. Stock awards generally vest over a four or five-year service\n period.\nExecutive incentive\n plan\n\nUnder the Executive\n Incentive Plan, the Compensation Committee approves stock awards to\n executive officers and certain senior executives. The stock awards\n vest ratably in August of each of the four years following the\n grant date.\nActivity for all stock\n plans\n\nThe fair value of stock\n awards were estimated on the date of grant using the following\n assumptions:\n\n \xa0\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\xa0\n\n \xa0\n\n \xa0\n\n \xa0\n\n\nYear Ended June\xa030,\n\xa0\xa0\n2016\n\xa0\n\xa0\n2015\n\xa0\n\xa0\n2014\n\xa0\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nDividends per share (quarterly\n amounts)\n\n\xa0\xa0\n$\n\xa0\xa00.31\xa0-\xa0$\xa0\xa00.36\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n$\n\xa0\xa00.28\xa0-\xa0$\xa0\xa00.31\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n$\n\xa0\xa00.23\xa0-\xa0$\xa0\xa00.28\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\nInterest rates\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n1.1%\xa0-1.8%\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n1.2%\xa0-\xa01.9%\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n1.3%\xa0-\xa01.8%\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nDuring fiscal year 2016,\n the following activity occurred under our stock plans:\n\n \xa0\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nShares\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\n\nWeighted\n\nAverage\n\nGrant-Date\n\nFair\n Value\n\n\xa0\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n(In\xa0millions)\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\n\n\n\n\n\nStock Awards\n\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nNonvested balance, beginning of\n year\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n216\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n$\n\xa0\xa032.72\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\nGranted\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n83\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n$\n\xa0\xa041.51\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\nVested\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n(85\n)\xa0\n\xa0\n$\n\xa0\xa030.98\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\nForfeited\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n(20\n)\xa0\n\xa0\n$\n\xa0\xa035.93\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\n\n\nNonvested balance, end of\n year\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n194\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n$\n\xa0\xa036.92\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\xa0\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\n\n\nAs of June\xa030, 2016,\n there was approximately $4.8 billion of total unrecognized\n compensation costs related to stock awards. These costs are\n expected to be recognized over a weighted average period of 3\n years. The weighted average grant-date fair value of stock award\n granted was $41.51, $42.36, and $31.50 for fiscal years 2016, 2015,\n and 2014, respectively. The fair value of stock awards vested was\n $3.9 billion, $4.2 billion, and $3.2 billion, for fiscal years\n 2016, 2015, and 2014, respectively.\n\n \xa0\nEmployee Stock Purchase\n Plan\n\nWe have an ESPP for all\n eligible employees. Shares of our common stock may be purchased by\n employees at three-month intervals at 90% of the fair market value\n on the last trading day of each three-month period. Employees may\n purchase shares having a value not exceeding 15% of their gross\n compensation during an offering period. Employees purchased the\n following shares during the periods presented:\n\n \xa0\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n(Shares in millions)\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nYear Ended June\xa030,\n\xa0\xa0\n2016\n\xa0\n\xa0\n2015\n\xa0\n\xa0\n2014\n\xa0\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nShares purchased\n\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n15\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n16\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n18\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\nAverage price per share\n\n\xa0\xa0\n$\n\xa0\xa044.83\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n$\n\xa0\xa039.87\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n$\n\xa0\xa033.60\n\xa0\xa0\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nAs of June\xa030, 2016,\n 142\xa0million shares of our common stock were reserved for\n future issuance through the ESPP.\nSavings Plan\n\nWe have a savings plan in\n the U.S. that qualifies under Section\xa0401(k) of the Internal\n Revenue Code, and a number of savings plans in international\n locations. Participating U.S. employees may contribute a portion of\n their salary, subject to certain limitations. Beginning January\n 2016, we contribute fifty cents for each dollar a participant\n contributes in this plan, with a maximum employer contribution of\n 50% of the IRS contribution limit for the calendar year. Prior to\n January 2016, we contributed fifty cents for each dollar of the\n first 6% a participant contributed in this plan, with a maximum\n contribution of the lesser of 3% of a participant’s earnings\n or 3% of the IRS compensation limit for the calendar year. Matching\n contributions for all plans were $549 million, $454 million, and\n $420 million in fiscal years 2016, 2015, and 2014, respectively,\n and were expensed as contributed.', '', '', '', '', '', ['SEGMENT INFORMATION AND GEOGRAPHIC DATA', '12 Months Ended']
['Jun. 30, 2016']
['SEGMENT INFORMATION AND GEOGRAPHIC DATA', 'NOTE 21\n — SEGMENT INFORMATION AND GEOGRAPHIC DATA\nIn its\n operation of the business, management, including our chief\n operating decision maker, reviews certain financial information,\n including segmented internal profit and loss statements prepared on\n a basis not consistent with U.S. GAAP.\nIn June\n 2015, we announced a change in organizational structure to align to\n our strategic direction as a productivity and platform company.\n During the first quarter of fiscal year 2016, our chief operating\n decision maker requested changes in the information that he\n regularly reviews for purposes of allocating resources and\n assessing performance. As a result, beginning in fiscal year 2016,\n we report our financial performance based on our new segments,\n Productivity and Business Processes, Intelligent Cloud, and More\n Personal Computing, and analyze operating income as the measure of\n segment profitability. We have recast certain prior period amounts\n to conform to the way we internally manage and monitor segment\n performance.\nOur\n reportable segments are described below.\n\nProductivity and\n Business Processes\nOur\n Productivity and Business Processes segment consists of products\n and services in our portfolio of productivity, communication, and\n information services, spanning a variety of devices and platforms.\n This segment primarily comprises:\n\n \xa0\n\n\n\xa0\n•\n\xa0\n\nOffice\n Commercial, including volume licensing and subscriptions to Office\n 365 commercial for products and services such as Office, Exchange,\n SharePoint, and Skype for Business, and related Client Access\n Licenses (“CALs”).\n\n\n\n\n \xa0\n\n\n\xa0\n•\n\xa0\n\nOffice\n Consumer, including Office sold through retail or through an Office\n 365 consumer subscription, and Office Consumer Services, including\n Skype, Outlook.com, and OneDrive.\n\n\n\n\n \xa0\n\n\n\xa0\n•\n\xa0\n\nDynamics business solutions, including Dynamics ERP products,\n Dynamics CRM on-premises, and Dynamics CRM Online.\n\n\n\n\n \xa0\n\nIntelligent\n Cloud\nOur\n Intelligent Cloud segment consists of our public, private, and\n hybrid server products and cloud services that can power modern\n business. This segment primarily comprises:\n\n \xa0\n\n\n\xa0\n•\n\xa0\n\nServer\n products and cloud services, including Microsoft SQL Server,\n Windows Server, Visual Studio, System Center, and related CALs, as\n well as Azure.\n\n\n\n\n \xa0\n\n\n\xa0\n•\n\xa0\n\nEnterprise Services, including Premier Support Services and\n Microsoft Consulting Services.\n\n\n\n\nMore Personal\n Computing\nOur More\n Personal Computing segment consists of products and services geared\n towards harmonizing the interests of end users, developers, and IT\n professionals across screens of all sizes. This segment primarily\n comprises:\n\n \xa0\n\n\n\xa0\n•\n\xa0\n\nWindows, including Windows original equipment manufacturer\n licensing (“Windows OEM”) and other non-volume\n licensing of the Windows operating system, volume licensing of the\n Windows operating system, patent licensing, Windows Embedded, MSN\n display advertising, and Windows Phone licensing.\n\n\n\n\n \xa0\n\n\n\xa0\n•\n\xa0\n\nDevices, including Surface, phones, and PC\n accessories.\n\n\n\n\n \xa0\n\n\n\xa0\n•\n\xa0\n\nGaming, including Xbox hardware; Xbox Live, comprising\n transactions, subscriptions, and advertising; video games; and\n third-party video game royalties.\n\n\n\n\n \xa0\n\n\n\xa0\n•\n\xa0\n\nSearch\n advertising.\n\n\n\nRevenue\n and costs are generally directly attributed to our segments.\n However, due to the integrated structure of our business, certain\n revenue recognized and costs incurred by one segment may benefit\n other segments. Revenue on certain contracts is allocated among the\n segments based on the relative value of the underlying products and\n services, which can include allocation based on actual prices\n charged, prices when sold separately, or estimated costs plus a\n profit margin. Cost of revenue is allocated in certain cases based\n on a relative revenue methodology. Operating expenses that are\n allocated primarily include those relating to marketing of products\n and services from which multiple segments benefit, and are\n generally allocated based on relative gross margin.\nIn\n addition, certain costs incurred at a corporate level that are\n identifiable and that benefit our segments are allocated to them.\n These allocated costs include costs of: legal, including\n settlements, and fines; information technology; human resources;\n finance; excise taxes; field selling; shared facilities services;\n and customer service and support. Each allocation is measured\n differently based on the specific facts and circumstances of the\n costs being allocated. Certain corporate-level activity is not\n allocated to our segments, including impairment, integration, and\n restructuring expenses.\nSegment\n revenue and operating income (loss) were as follows during the\n periods presented:\n\n \xa0\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n(In millions)\n\xa0\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\xa0\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nYear Ended ["- DefinitionThe entire disclosure for reporting segments including data and tables. Reportable segments include those that meet any of the following quantitative thresholds a) it's reported revenue, including sales to external customers and intersegment sales or transfers is 10 percent or more of the combined revenue, internal and external, of all operating segments b) the absolute amount of its reported profit or loss is 10 percent or more of the greater, in absolute amount of 1) the combined reported profit of all operating segments that did not report a loss or 2) the combined reported loss of all operating segments that did report a loss c) its assets are 10 percent ['- DefinitionThe entire disclosure for quarterly financial data. Includes, but is not limited to, tabular presentation of financial information for fiscal quarters, effect of year-end adjustments, and an explanation of matters or transactions that affect comparability of the information.\n+ ReferencesReference 1: http://www.xbrl.org/2003/role/presentationRef -Publisher FASB -Name Accounting Standards Codification -Topic 270 -SubTopic 10 -Section 50 -Paragraph 2 -URI http://asc.fasb.org/extlink&oid=68076893&loc=d3e1570-108306Reference 2: http://www.xbrl.org/2003/role/presentationRef -Publisher FASB -Name Accounting Standards Codification -Topic 270 -SubTopic 10 -Section 45 -Paragraph 13 -URI http://asc.fasb.org/extlink&oid=68064558&loc=d3e765-108305Reference 3: http://www.xbrl.org/2003/role/presentationRef -Publisher FASB -Name Accounting Standards Codification -Topic 270 -SubTopic 10 -Section 45 -Paragraph 12 -URI http://asc.fasb.org/extlink&oid=68064558&loc=d3e725-108305\n+ Details\n\n Name:\nus-gaap_QuarterlyFinancialInformationTextBlock\n\n\n Namespace Prefix:\nus-gaap_\n\n\n Data Type:\nnonnum:textBlockItemType\n\n\n Balance Type:\nna\n\n\n Period Type:\nduration', 'Name:', 'us-gaap_QuarterlyFinancialInformationTextBlock', 'Namespace Prefix:', 'us-gaap_', 'Data Type:', 'nonnum:textBlockItemType', 'Balance Type:', 'na', 'Period Type:', 'duration']

['Name:', 'us-gaap_QuarterlyFinancialInformationTextBlock']
['Namespace Prefix:', 'us-gaap_']
